questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with frequent headaches. Investigation reveals raised intracranial pressure and the presence of a dural-based tumor. Which of the following histological findings correlate with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a dural-based tumor presenting with headaches and raised intracranial pressure is most likely a meningioma and they have psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells on histopathological examination.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.

  • Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.
  • Prior radiation therapy to the head and neck, typically is a risk factor.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is the loss of chromosome 22, especially the long arm (22q).
  • Meningiomas are a common lesion in the setting of NF2 (multiple sites, especially in association with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.
  • The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated.
  • They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura. This form is commonly associated with hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone.
  • The lesions may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies.

Psammoma bodies are shown below:

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, choroid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

Option A: Fried egg appearance of cells refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus. Fried egg appearance in pathology are:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma/Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

Option B: Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes with arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen can be seen in retinoblastoma.

Option D: In medulloblastoma, tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neurophil can be seen.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with CSF otorrhea?

choices.text: Traumatic rupture of the tympanic membrane
Fracture of the roof of the nose

questions.solution:
A battle sign is seen in CSF otorrhea.

Battle sign refers to the retro auricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of the middle cranial fossa following head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of the temporal bone. CSF leak is associated with head trauma and fracture of the temporal bone. It can present as CSF otorrhea or CSF rhinorrhea or both.

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa. 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Spontaneous resolution is seen within 14 days. Perioperative fluorescein cisternography is used for identifying the site of leakage. Persistent CSF leaks and large tegmen defects are treated with surgery due to the risk of herniation of the meninges and the brain.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.
  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

Note: Reservoir sign is also seen in acute mastoiditis/ coalescent mastoiditis where mastoid acts as a reservoir of pus and pus reappear in EAC immediately after cleaning.

questions.text: The first heart sound coincides with which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
The first heart sound coincides with the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.

The time between the closure of the mitral valve and the opening of the aortic valve is the isovolumic contraction period. It begins with the closure of mitral and tricuspid valve which is responsible for the first heart sound. During this period, the ventricles contract as a closed chamber till the aortic and pulmonary valves open. 

Events of the Cardiac Cycle

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP.

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: Gonadal growth corresponds with?
questions.solution:
Gonadal growth corresponds with a growth spurt during puberty that results in somatic or skeletal growth.

Gonadal growth is dormant during childhood and becomes prominent during puberty. Skeletal growth is a continuous process that is steady until the pubertal growth spurt during which it accelerates. Skeletal maturity is achieved when the epiphysis/growth plates fuse with the shaft/diaphysis, around 18 years in girls and 20-22 years in boys. The degree of skeletal maturation closely correlates with the degree of sexual maturation. A child who has advanced sexual maturity will also have earlier skeletal maturation.

Other options:

Option B: Brain growth occurs during the later part of fetal life and first two years. The head is around 65-70% of adult size at birth and reaches 90% by the age of 2 years. 

Option C: Lymphoid growth is prominent in the mid-childhood. It peaks at 4–8 years when the lymphoid tissue overgrows and may appear to be larger than that adult. This can be evident in the form of enlarged tonsils and palpable lymph nodes that regresses subsequently and reach adult size.

Option D: Dental growth has no correlation with gonadal growth.

questions.text: Hemoglobin with iron in ferric form is _______
questions.solution:
Hemoglobin with iron in ferric form is methemoglobin.

Hemoglobin structure:

  • Each consists of a tetramer of globin polypeptide chains: a pair of α-like chains and a pair of β-like chains.
    • HbA (α2β2): Major adult hemoglobin
    • HbF (α2γ2): Fetal Hemoglobin
    • HbA2 (α2δ2): Minor adult hemoglobin
  • Each globin chain enfolds a single heme moiety, consisting of a protoporphyrin IX ring complexed with a single iron atom in the ferrous state (Fe2+).
  • Each heme moiety can bind a single oxygen molecule.
  • The hemoglobin tetramer is highly soluble, but individual globin chains are insoluble.
  • Unpaired globin precipitates, forming inclusions that damage the cell and can trigger apoptosis.

Methemoglobin is formed when hemoglobin is oxidized to contain iron in the ferric [Fe3+] rather than the normal ferrous [Fe2+] state. The presence of iron in the ferric state results shift of the oxygen-dissociation curve to the left. This shift leads to increased affinity of the ferrous iron for oxygen and thus impaired oxygen release to the tissue.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with left testicular carcinoma. Which of the following lymph nodes is the first to be involved?
questions.solution:
In a patient with testicular carcinoma, para-aortic lymph nodes are the first to be involved.

The lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes near the origin of the gonadal vessels. The contralateral para-aortic lymph nodes are sometimes involved in tumor spread, but the inguinal lymph nodes are affected only if the scrotal skin is involved.

questions.text: What type of cell is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
In the picture given above, Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed–Sternberg cells :

  • RS cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (thus resembling an "owl's eye" appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli.
  • The RS cell is clonal in origin and arises from the germinal center B cells but typically has lost most B-cell gene expression and function.
  • Reed Sternberg cells are not diagnostic for any condition since they are seen in many conditions such as:
    • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
    • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (commonly in immunoblastic type)
    • Infectious mononucleosis
    • Sarcomas


Option A: Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as “Faggot cells” and are marked in the image below by the red arrow (faggot in French means bundle of sticks). 


Option C: Mott cells are plasma cells with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies. They are characteristically seen in multiple myeloma.


Option D: Sézary-Lutzner cells are cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane). These are neoplastic T cells that are seen in mycosis fungoides and Sezary syndrome.

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

Variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

  • Lacunar Variant: Nodular Sclerosis
  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: A child has elevated liver enzyme levels. A ring-like structure is noted on ocular examination as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the cause for this?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of elevated liver enzymes and Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image is suggestive of Wilson's disease. KF ring is formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor 
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state, therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

The image below is that of a patient with a KF ring and a sunflower cataract:

Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show:

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to a marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

questions.text: The urban area of Delhi has 4000 population with different religions. Research is being done to study the dietary habits of the population. Which of the following techniques can be used to obtain a study sample?
questions.solution:
Stratified random sampling is the ideal sampling method for this study.

In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups or strata which in this case would be religion. Random samples are drawn from each stratum such that the sample represents the population from all strata.

In this case, the researcher wants to conduct a dietary survey on a population with people of different religions (heterogeneous population). The best method to obtain a sample is to stratify them based on religion and choose a set number of people from each religion so that the final sample represents people from all the religions.

Other options:

Option A: Cluster random sampling involves grouping the population into clusters which contain a set number of people(example a cluster of 3) and selecting few clusters to make the sample for study.

Option C: In simple random sampling people are randomly selected after assigning a number to each individual in the population. In this study with people of different religions, making a simple selection would not provide a sample that equally represents people from all religion.

Option D: Systematic random sampling involves numbering the study population and selecting individual at a regular interval like every 5th or every 10th.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • A random is defined by the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.
  • For example, picking 4 random cards from a bag full of cards.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • For example, if a researcher wants to do a study on 100 doctors working in hospitals in Bangalore, he would select a cluster of 10 hospitals (clusters) and then take 10 doctors from each hospital as part his sample.
  • This is usually done when large scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 10th person to be admitted to the hospital can be selected or every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The sinus marked in the non-contrast CT image is the maxillary sinus.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities in that are present in the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: It includes,

  • Maxillary sinus(Antrum of highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal.

All of the above sinuses open in the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to basal lamella of middle turbinate.

Posterior group: It includes,

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess.

Note: 

Maxillary and Ethmoid sinuses( including both anterior and posterior ethmoidal sinuses) are present at birth. The frontal and the sphenoid sinuses are not present at birth.

questions.text: Which of the following cell pathways occurs exclusively in cell cytoplasm?
questions.solution:
Among the given options glycolysis occurs exclusively in the cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Beta oxidation (oxidation of fatty acids) occurs in mitochondria.

Option B: TCA cycle/citric acid cycle occurs in mitochondria.

Option D: The urea cycle occurs both in the cytoplasm and mitochondria.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies in liver sinusoids?
questions.solution:
Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages of the liver that are responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies. These cells are present in the walls of the sinusoids and not in the perisinusoidal space (Space of Disse). They are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Macrophages can be divided into:

  • Blood macrophages (monocytes) are the largest of the lymphoid cells in the peripheral blood. Life span: 3 days. 
  • Tissue macrophages survive for months. 

2 main functions of macrophages:

  • Phagocytosis.
  • Antigen presentation.

All the options given are various types of cells present in an adult liver.

Option A: Hepatocytes are polyhedral cells with a central spherical nucleus, arranged in a single-cell layer. Every hepatocyte has contact with adjacent hepatocytes (with gap junctions for intercellular communication), bile canaliculus, and the space of Disse/perisinusoidal space (hepatocytes project multiple microvilli into this space for active transport of substances.)

Option B: Ito cells or hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and store vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin and take part in the development of hepatic fibrosis.

Option C: Sinusoidal endothelial cells are flat cells with a central nucleus and are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles. These are separated from hepatocytes by the space of Disse (perisinusoidal space).

questions.text: A 35-year-old  woman takes aspirin for a headache, later she presented with wheezing and breathlessness. These symptoms are likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of aspirin intolerance. It is most likely to be associated with nasal polyps. 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided due to the risk of the development of aspirin intolerance.

Samter triad is a non-IgE mediated hypersensitivity reaction associated with the intake of aspirin or other cyclooxygenase inhibitors. Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

Patients with Samter's triad will have persistent nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, anosmia, nasal polyps, and recurrent chronic rhinosinusitis. Asthma and aspirin intolerance develop later.

Acute asthma attacks usually occur 3 hours after intake of aspirin or NSAIDs. Severe rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur. 

Patients should avoid aspirin and NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1. Treatment may involve aspirin desensitization and endoscopic sinus surgery.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: 3 months following cataract surgery, a patient comes with complaints of decreased visual acuity. On examination, posterior capsular opacification is seen. What type of laser can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given history mentions decreased visual acuity 3 months post-cataract surgery and the presence of posterior capsular opacification is suggestive of after-cataract. A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment.

Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

Treatment:

  • Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy: The laser used in posterior capsulotomy is Nd: YAG laser (1064 nm) whose principle is photodisruption. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and disrupts the tissues creating an opening.
  • Surgical treatment: Posterior capsular opacification is managed by creating an opening on the posterior capsule along the visual axis, a procedure called a posterior capsulotomy.

Related Pearl: Lasers in Ophthalmology

Laser Wavelength (Nanometers) Clinical applications

  • Posterior capsulotomy
  • Iridotomy
  • Hyloidotomy
Frequency doubled Nd:YAG 532

  • Trabeculoplasty
  • Iridoplasty

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a 2-year-old child gives a history of completing required antenatal vaccinations during her previous pregnancy. Which of the following would you recommend for her current pregnancy?

choices.text: Give a booster dose of TT
Give a booster dose of Td

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of a mother who was vaccinated in her previous pregnancy 2 years ago, a booster dose of Td (tetanus and adult diphtheria) is recommended.

All pregnant women must be vaccinated with 0.5 ml, intramuscular Td in the upper arm to prevent neonatal and maternal tetanus.

  • Unimmunized women should receive two doses of Td vaccine with the first dose given as early as possible. The second dose should have at least one month gap and be given at least 3 weeks before delivery to allow sufficient time for developing antibodies.
  • Previously immunized women just require a booster Td if the current pregnancy occurred within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

The guidelines recommend replacing TT with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women and isolated tetanus toxoid is no longer recommended.

questions.text:
Which of these drugs stimulates PPAR- alpha?

PPAR alpha-Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha
questions.solution:
Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that stimulates PPAR (Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor) alpha.

Fibrates bind to PPAR alpha and cause stimulation of lipoprotein lipase enzyme. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is a key enzyme in the degradation of VLDL. Increased LPL synthesis enhances the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Additionally, fibrates also stimulate fatty acid oxidation and reduce the expression of apo C-III (inhibitor of lipolysis).

Gemfibrozil is a first line drug for patients with markedly raised triglyceride levels. Episodes of acute pancreatitis are prevented in patients with chylomicronaemia and severe hypertriglyceridaemia. It is most effective in type III hyperlipoproteinaemia.

Other options:

Option B: Ezetimibe is a novel drug that acts by inhibiting intestinal absorption of dietary as well as biliary cholesterol by interfering with a specific cholesterol transporter protein in the intestinal mucosa.

Option C: Colestipol are bile acid sequestrants which are basic ion exchange resins supplied in the chloride form. They have been shown to retard atherosclerosis and coronary events.

Opttion D: Simvastatin competitively inhibit conversion of 3-Hydroxy-3-methyl glutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) to mavalonate by the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase. This is the rate limiting step in the cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following dimorphic fungi causes subcutaneous mycosis?
questions.solution:
The dimorphic fungus that causes subcutaneous mycosis is Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporotrichosis is caused by Sporothrix schenckii, a thermally dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation. The infection occurs following traumatic inoculation.

The lesion initially develops as a granulomatous nodule that may progress to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. The infection from the lesions in the skin and subcutaneous tissue can spread via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes. This condition is known as lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. This disease is commonly encountered among gardeners and forest workers.

The image below shows lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

Other options:

Option B: Histoplasmosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungi Histoplasma capsulatum. It is acquired by inhalation and causes a disease similar to tuberculosis and may present as fever, chills, headache, dry cough, dyspnea, and chest pain.

Option C: Blastomycosis is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is contracted through the inhalation of contaminated soil. Primary infection usually presents as pneumonia.  Chest X-ray reveals consolidation. Disseminated disease may lead to multiple abscesses. Cutaneous lesions present as papules and nodules which progress into large ulcerative lesions.

Option D: T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man dies due to myocardial infarction. Which of the following stains can be used to see the infarct in the heart while conducting an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain can be used to see the infarct in the heart.

Myocardial infarcts less than 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to highlight the area of necrosis by immersion of tissue slices in a solution of triphenyl tetrazolium chloride.

This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, noninfarcted myocardium where lactate dehydrogenase activity is preserved. Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.

Other options:

Option A: The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain. It can identify neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues.

Option C: Sudan Black B (SBB) is a lipophilic dye that binds irreversibly to an undefined granule component in granulocytes, eosinophils, and some monocytes. It stains intracellular lipids and phospholipids.

Option D: Collagen fibres are stained blue and muscle fibres are stained red using Masson trichrome stain.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition shown in the graph.
questions.solution:
The above graph is called a 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot and it represents noncompetitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition: When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition,

  • Vmax decreases.(1/Vmax increases)
  • Km remains constant.

In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Competitive inhibition - Here, the inhibitor is a structural analog of the substrate. Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme. Here Vmax is unchanged (same y-intercept), and Km is increased (− 1/Km moves closer to zero from a negative value).

Uncompetitive inhibition  - Here, the inhibitor does not have any affinity for the free enzyme. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, but not to the free enzyme. Here, both Vmax and Km are decreased.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: Identify the given histology slide:
questions.solution:
The above image shows pancreatic islet cells. Islet of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers, and containing numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. They are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

The image given below shows the histology of the pancreas.

The islets of Langerhans contain four major and two minor cell types:

Four main types are β, α, δ, and PP (pancreatic polypeptide) cells:

  • α or A cells- located peripherally and secrete glucagon 
  • β or B cells- located centrally and produce insulin 
  • δ or D cells- scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin
  • PP cells- are present in islets and also in the exocrine pancreas. They secrete a pancreatic polypeptide, which exerts several gastrointestinal effects, such as stimulation of secretion of gastric and intestinal enzymes and inhibition of intestinal motility. 

Minor cell types:

  • D1 cells secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), a hormone that induces glycogenolysis and hyperglycemia. It also stimulates gastrointestinal fluid secretion and causes secretory diarrhea.
  • Enterochromaffin cells synthesize serotonin and are the source of pancreatic tumors that cause carcinoid syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. The structure of lymph nodes consists of an outer cortex and inner medulla. The cortex contains an aggregation of B-lymphocytes (primary follicles) and quiescent secondary follicles with a pale central germinal center.

The inner medulla consists of medullary cords (lymphocytes and plasma cells) and medullary sinuses. Between the cortex and medulla, there is an ill-defined zone called the paracortex, which contains T lymphocytes.

The image given below shows the histology of the lymph node. 

Option B: Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries. The glomerular capillary wall is the filtering membrane and consists of fenestrated endothelial cells, basement membrane, and visceral epithelial cells called podocytes, which contain foot processes.

The image given below shows the histology of the glomerulus.

Option C: Spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ. It contains round white pulp surrounded by red pulp. The white pulp is made up of aggregations of lymphocytes that surround a small artery or arterioles.

The red pulp is a modified lymphoid tissue infiltrated with all the cells of circulating blood. It is like a sponge permeated by spaces (splenic sinusoids) lined by reticular cells. The zone of red pulp immediately surrounding white pulp is the marginal zone. This zone has a rich network of sinusoids.

The image given below shows the histology of the spleen.

questions.text: Which among the following culture media is used in the identification of Salmonella?
questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium is used for the identification of Salmonella. It is a type of selective and indicator media. 

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

On Deoxycholate citrate media and XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate), colonies show blackheads due to H2S production.

Other options:

Option 1) PLET medium is used to isolate B. anthracis. It is a selective medium consisting of polymyxin, lysozyme, ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA), and thallous acetate added to heart infusion agar.

Option 2) BCYE medium (Buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella.

Option 4) Stuart Transport Medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to the laboratory.

The image below shows black colonies of Salmonella.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases uric acid in urine?
questions.solution:
Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acid.

Probenecid is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. The drug acts by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubules that are involved in uric acid reabsorption. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia.

Probenecid increases urinary urate levels. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation. Probenecid should not be used in gouty patients with nephrolithiasis or with overproduction of uric acid.

Probenecid inhibits penicillin's urinary excretion, prolonging penicillin action by enhancing and sustaining their blood levels. It inhibits the urinary excretion of other drugs such as cephalosporins, sulfonamides, methotrexate, and indomethacin. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of the drug.

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall it reduces the inflammatory response.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme that prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

questions.text: Following urine microscopy and examination, a child is found to have hematuria and RBC casts in the urine. What is the probable cause for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of nephritic syndrome (hematuria and red cell casts) seen in this child is most likely due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN) is characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It usually occurs following a throat infection by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. It can also occur after streptococcal skin infection or pyoderma.

The typical patient develops an acute nephritic syndrome following:
  • 1 to 2 weeks after antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or
  • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

The pathogenesis involves circulating antibodies elicited by streptococcal antigens reacting with normal glomerular antigens, and complement activation by directly deposited streptococcal antigens causing the immunologic injury.

In this immune complex-mediated APSGN, we see the following in most patients:

  • Decrease in the serum complement (C3) level (levels normalize in 6 to 8 weeks)
  • ASO titer is increased (the titers decrease to low levels within 4 to 6 weeks)
Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration
  • Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or humps, are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Hematuria is not a usual feature of nephrotic syndrome and rather presents with nephrotic range proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema.

Option C: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) present in adolescents or young adults with nephrotic syndrome and a nephritic component manifested by hematuria. It is not frequent in children.

Option D: Minimal change disease is the most frequent cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: The major thyroxine-binding protein is _____.
questions.solution:
Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) is the major protein that binds to thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine. 

Thyroid hormones bind to transthyretin and albumin to a much lesser extent than TBG. 

Hormones and their Binding Proteins  

  1. T4  and T3  bind to thyroxine-binding globulin  (TBG), albumin, and thyroxine-binding pre-albumin (TBPA)  
  2. Cortisol binds to cortisol-binding globulin (CBG);  
  3. Androgen and estrogen bind to sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG);  
  4. IGF-I and -II bind to multiple IGF-binding proteins (IGFBPs);  
  5. GH interacts with GH-binding protein (GHBP), a circulating fragment of the GH receptor extracellular domain;
  6. Activin binds to follistatin.

questions.text: In the given barium swallow image, which of the following shows the left atrium impression on the esophagus?
questions.solution:
In the given barium swallow image, the arrow marking with the number 3 shows the left atrium impression on the esophagus.

The esophagus is a fibromuscular tube that connects the pharynx of the neck to the stomach, passing through the thorax through the superior and posterior mediastinum. It starts below the cricopharyngeus muscle, at the level of C6- the cricoid cartilage's bottom margin. The esophagus is located behind the trachea in the neck. It passes posterior to the left main bronchus, the left atrium, and the aortic arch as it descends through the mediastinum, each of which leaves an impression.

The vagus nerves accompany the esophagus as it travels through the diaphragmatic gap at T10 and finishes at the gastric cardia at T11. The left lobe of the liver is located anterior to the abdominal esophagus. Thus, the esophagus is composed of a short cervical, a long thoracic, and a short abdominal segment.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought for complaints of short stature. His height is comparable with his parent's height and his bone age corresponds to his chronological age. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with short stature with his height comparable to his parent's height and bone age that equals chronological age, the likely diagnosis is familial short stature.

This child's height is normal according to his genetic potential determined by the parent's height. The body proportion is appropriate and bone age equals the chronological age with normal growth velocity. They achieve puberty at an appropriate age and their final height is within their target range.

The relationship between bone age and chronological age is summarised below

  • Bone age = chronological age in familial short stature
  • Bone age > chronological age in precocious puberty
  • Bone age < chronological age in other causes like constitutional delay, undernutrition, genetic diseases, and endocrine causes. 

Other options:

Option B: Children with constitutional delay are normal during the first year and fall behind till 3 years, after which the velocity becomes normal. Bone age is lower than chronological age(corresponds to the height age). The onset of puberty is also delayed and they achieve a normal final height. History of delayed puberty and delayed height spurt is usually present in one or both parents.

Option C: Children with undernutrition show other features of malnutrition such as low mid-upper arm circumference and low weight, with a bone age lower than chronological age.

Option D: Children with growth hormone deficiency have bone age lower than chronological age and other signs like crowding of mid-facial structures, and depressed nasal bridge.

Related Pearl: Short stature: Familial vs Constitutional

Feature Constitutional Delay Familial Short Stature  
Height Short Short
Final Height Normal Short  
Family history Delayed puberty Short stature  
Bone age Less than chronological age Normal  
Puberty Delayed Normal  
Height velocity Normal Normal

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with an abnormal gait. On examination, when the patient was asked to stand on the left foot, a right-sided hip drop was observed. Which of the following muscles are paralyzed in this patient?

choices.text: Right gluteus maximus and gluteus medius
Right gluteus medius and gluteus minimus
Left gluteus maximus and gluteus medius
Left gluteus medius and gluteus minimus

questions.solution:
The examination of the patient indicates a positive Trendelenburg's sign (Trendelenburg's gait), with sagging on the right side. It is seen in paralysis of the left gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles which are supplied by the left superior gluteal nerve. 

The superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus.

Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus: 

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in the slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb.

Inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle.

The below GIF shows a positive Trendelenburg's sign (Trendelenburg's gait) with a left superior gluteal nerve injury. 

In the GIF, when the person lifts up his right leg and tries to stand on the left leg, the right pelvis tilts down. This shows that the left side abduction mechanism is paralyzed and the right side is normal. The left superior gluteal nerve is injured in this case since it supplies the left gluteus medius and minimus.

Note: These patients can also have a characteristic lurching gait.

questions.text: A 2-year-old was brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last few hours. The X-ray is given below. Which is the next best step to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given x-rays are suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin/disc battery.

The given x-rays are anteroposterior and lateral views of the chest and neck. Coins, disk batteries, and small toy items are commonly ingested by children. 

The flat surface of a coin in the esophagus is seen on the anteroposterior view (AP view) i.e; they are oriented in the coronal plane. The edge is seen on the lateral view. Coins lying in the esophagus tend to lie in the coronal plane, whereas coins lying in the trachea lie in the sagittal plane.

Presenting symptoms are choking, gagging, and coughing followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat. Respiratory distress is seen if the esophageal foreign body impinges on the larynx or tracheal wall.

Imaging with PA and lateral views of the chest and abdomen should be done. 

Treatment includes the removal of the foreign body by esophagoscopy.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of RCH program?
questions.solution:
The Reproductive and child health program(RCH) does not include women's education and empowerment as a component.

RCH program deals with the health status of young women and young children. The main objectives are reducing the total fertility rate, infant mortality rate and maternal mortality rate. It involves the following components:

  • Essential and emergency obstetric care
  • Control of reproductive tract infections (RTI) and sexually transmitted diseases (STD)
  • Safe abortion services
  • Full range of family planning services including laparoscopic services
  • Essential newborn care and immunization
  • Emergency care of sick children including diarrhoeal and acute respiratory disease
  • Prevention and control of vitamin A deficiency and anaemia in children.

questions.text: A primigravida delivers a healthy baby via normal delivery. After how many hours should she initiate breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
In this scenario of a healthy mother and infant, breastfeeding should be started within 1 hour.

Breastmilk is the ideal and exclusively food for infants in the first 6 months. It reduces the infant mortality rate, neonatal hypocalcaemia and hypomagnesemia hence  should be started as soon possible.

The standard essential newborn care include:

  • Maintain the airway and breathing
  • Maintain the body temperature and prevent hypothermia
  • Initiate breastfeeding within one hour
  • Cleaning of baby and care to prevent infection
  • Cord care and care of the eyes
  • Administering vitamin K
  • Performing a thoroiugh examination.

 

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduces mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)?
questions.solution:
Metoprolol reduces mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF are :

  1. Beta-blockers block β1 receptors and prevent ventricular remodeling promoted by the stimulated RAAS and sympathetic system. Metoprolol and bisoprolol are selective for the β1 receptor, and carvedilol also blocks the β2 and α1 receptors, leading to vasodilation. Adverse effects include fluid retention, worsening HFrEF, fatigue, bradycardia or heart block, and hypotension. 
  2. ACE inhibitors- Enalapril and lisinopril also reduce mortality. ACE inhibitors decrease peripheral resistance and reduce the load on the failing myocardium by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. Hereby, preventing vasoconstriction and causing relaxation of the vasculature. 
  3. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)-  They inhibit the renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS) by blocking the binding of angiotensin II to its receptor, which in turn leads to vasoconstriction and prevents the release of aldosterone. They are found to reduce mortality and morbidity in HFrEF cases.
  4. Angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)- Sacubitril/valsartan is a novel therapy that has been approved in July 2015 to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and hospitalization for patients with HFrEF. Sacubitril/valsartan consists of the neprilysin inhibitor sacubitril and the ARB valsartan.
  5. Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone

Diuretics like furosemide and torsemide are not found to reduce mortality or hospital readmission. They are the only agents that can adequately control the fluid retention associated with HFrEF. 

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide is synthesized from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalyzed by NO synthase. 

Arginine, O2, and NADPH are substrates for cytosolic NO synthase. The co-enzymes of NO synthase include flavin mononucleotide (FMN), flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), heme, and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).

Functions of NO:

  • It is a potent vasodilator.
  • It acts as a neurotransmitter in CNS.
  • Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells.
  • Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation.
  • In GIT, it relaxes smooth muscle.

 

 

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones According to their Chemical Structure

  • Pituitary hormones - GH, ACTH, FSH, LH, Prolactin, Oxytocin and ADH
  • Insulin and glucagon
  • Parathormone

Steroid hormones

  • Cortisol, aldosterone
  • Estrogen, progesterone
  • Testosterone

Derivatives of a specific amino acid

  • Tyrosine
    • Thyroid hormones, catecholamines
  • Tryptophan
    • Serotonin (5-HT), melatonin
  • Arginine
    • Nitric oxide

questions.text: Which of the following is a sensitive and specific marker of intestinal inflammation?
questions.solution:
Fecal lactoferrin, a glycoprotein present in activated neutrophils is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation. It is a marker of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and is used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome. 

Fecal calprotectin present in neutrophils and monocytes is another marker of IBD and is used to rule out irritable bowel syndrome and bacterial overgrowth. It correlates well with histologic inflammation, predicts relapses, and detects pouchitis.

Option A: Procalcitonin is a commonly used biomarker of severe inflammation. It is an acute-phase reactant produced primarily in the liver, and is more significantly elevated in bacterial than viral infections.

Option C: Tissue transglutaminase IgA test is used in screening for celiac disease.

Option D: C-reactive protein is an acute-phase reactant synthesized primarily by the liver. CRP expression is increased by a number of inflammatory mediators, particularly IL-6.

questions.text: Asbestos exposure may be associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis is most commonly associated with Mesotheliomas. 

Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Pleural effusion
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

Asbestosis:

  • Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. However, once established, it progresses even in the further removal of the worker from its contact. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.
  • Asbestos is of 2 types i.e Serpentine/Chrysolite variety and Amphibole type
  • Amphibole type has the following varieties:
    • Crocidolite(blue)
    • Amosite(brown)
    • Anthophyllite(white)
  • Sputum shows asbestos bodies, which are asbestos fibers coated with fibrin.
  • They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea and predominantly affect the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • X-ray shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower zones. HRCT shows subpleural fibrotic lines, irregular opacities, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing. Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years).
  • The complications that can occur are
    • Pulmonary fibrosis 
    • Carcinoma of the lung 
    • Malignancy of the Gastrointestinal tract
    • Mesothelioma of the pleura

Preventive measures:

  • Using a safer type of Asbestos (chrysolite and amosite)
  • Substituting other insulants like glass fiber, mineral wool, calcium silicate, plastic foams, etc.
  • Dust control
  • Periodic examination of workers
  • Continuing research

Option B: Acute myeloid leukemia may be caused by benzene exposure.

Option C: Hepatic angiosarcoma can be seen in exposure to vinyl chloride.

Option D: Skin carcinoma may be seen with exposure to arsenic and arsenic compounds.

questions.text: A patient who presents to the OPD has a visual field defect as shown below. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma marked as 3 in the image given. 

Options marked in the image are:

1. Left optic nerve 
3. Otic chiasma
4. Left optic tract 
5. Left lateral geniculate nucleus

Hemianopia or hemianopsia refers to loss of sight in half the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours. Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, and suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia to emphasize the fact that the parts of the visual field that are lost in each eye do not overlap.

Individuals with this condition are able to see in both left and right central visual fields, with both eyes open. However, all information from the most peripheral parts of visual fields (which are seen only by the nasal retinas) is lost.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A truck driver comes with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Which of the following investigations can be used to diagnose the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy which can be used in a low economic, low resource setting. 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallidum. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

  • Treponemes generally are short and slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

The image given below shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by dark ground microscopy.

Other options:

Option B: HSV 2 antibody is used in the diagnosis of herpes genitalis. It is an infection of the genital skin or mucosa caused by  HSV 2 predominantly. It presents as painful genital ulcers and dysuria. It is usually preceded by a prodrome of general malaise.

Option C: The granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria take up bluish purple color when stained with Albert's stain. Albert’s stain, Neisser’s, and Ponder’s stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Option D: Acid-fast stain is used in the Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for the identification of acid-fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

  • Primary Syphilis:

Chancre- Painless, indurated, usually single

Lymphadenopathy- Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

Dory flop sign- As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

 

Secondary Syphilis:

A & B: Generalized rash(non-itchy, no vesicles, and palm and sole involvement).

This is the most common lesion.

C & D: Condyloma lata.

E: Moth-eaten alopecia (Non-scarring)

F: Mucous patches(Flat erosions on the tongue which can coalesce and form snail track ulcers).These are the most infectious lesions.

G: Pigmentary plaques

H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Tertiary Syphilis:

Gummatous syphilis(deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor)

Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

CVS-Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

CNS-General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

 

Latent Syphilis-Period between secondary and tertiary syphilis, when the patient is asymptomatic clinically, and only serological evidence of infection is present.

  • Early latent- Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent- After 1 year of infection

questions.text:
A large 'V' wave on jugular venous examination is seen in ______

JVP- Jugular venous pulse
questions.solution:
A large 'V' wave on JV examination is seen in tricuspid regurgitation.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation

questions.text: A patient presents to you with pain and redness in the right eye following an injury during welding. On examination, the image as seen below is observed. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A history of injury to the eye while welding along with the the given image is suggestive of a superficial foreign body in the eye. Removal of the foreign body using a 26G needle is the next step in the management of this patient.

Foreign bodies, which are usually small particles of dust, iron, steel, etc., may impinge upon the conjunctiva or cornea and cause sudden discomfort and reflex blinking. The foreign body sticks to the palpebral conjunctiva and is liable to be dragged across the cornea, causing excoriation. Particles of steel and iron fly straight onto the cornea and penetrate the epithelium or substantia propria.

Fluorescein or oblique illumination of the anesthetized eye with a slit lamp can be used to determine the position of a foreign body. If not removed, they expose the cornea to organisms in the conjunctival sac causing ulceration and extrusion of the foreign body in the slough. The ulcer thus formed may heal, but if virulent organisms are present, a spreading ulcer, with or without hypopyon, may develop.

Foreign bodies are managed by removal as soon as possible. 

  • If the foreign body is found lying loose in either fornix, it can be removed with a clean swab after everting the eyelids.
  • Double-eversion of the upper eyelid with a Desmarres retractor can be done if required.
  • If embedded in the bulbar conjunctiva or cornea, it can be removed by a foreign body spud or fine forceps under topical anesthesia.
  • A disposable hypodermic (26 or 27 gauge) needle can be used.

Following removal in all cases, an antibiotic ointment should be applied and the eye kept bandaged for a day. Foreign bodies in the eye are extremely common in industrial workers, especially in those working with grinding tools, lathe work, or hammering on a chisel, and thus eye must be protected by educative notices, lectures, and the provision of comfortable goggles.

Cases of ferruginous intraocular foreign bodies (IOFB) may give rise to anterior capsular cataracts and reddish-brown staining of the iris leading to heterochromia iridis. MRI is contraindicated here and instead, CT with axial and coronal cuts is used to localize a metallic IOFB. Magnetic removal is done for the removal of ferrous foreign bodies.

questions.text: Which among the following helps in the maturation of collagen?
questions.solution:
Ascorbic acid/Vitamin C helps in the maturation of collagen. 

Collagen is synthesized intracellularly in fibroblasts. Each polypeptide chain of collagen has about 1000 amino acid residues composed of Glycine-X-Y repeats, where X and Y are proline and hydroxyproline predominantly.

Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues takes place intracellularly as a part of post-translational modification with the help of prolyl hydroxylase and lysyl hydroxylase. These enzymes require iron in a reduced state in its active site. Vitamin C/ascorbic acid keeps iron in a reduced state in these enzymes and thus helps in the maturation of collagen. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy which is characterized by bleeding tendencies, anemia, and skeletal abnormalities due to defective collagen in the connective tissue.

Steps of post-translational modification of collagen includes

  • Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues
  • Glycosylation of hydroxylysine residues
  • Formation of intrachain and interchain disulfide bonds
  • Triple helix formation
  • Cleavage of 25–35 kDa portions at both carboxy and amino terminal end
  • Quartered staggered arrangement
  • Oxidative deamination of lysine and hydroxylysine residues
  • Formation of intrachain and interchain crosslinks

Other options:

Option B: Lysyl oxidase is a copper-containing enzyme that helps in covalent crosslinking collagen fibers. Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase, and reduced cross-linkage of collagen leading to a condition called Menke's disease. Zinc has no role in collagen maturation.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Which of the following is an acid-fast organism?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium avium is an acid-fast organism.

Mycobacterium avium complex consists of multiple nontuberculosis mycobacterial species (NTM), which cannot be distinguished in the microbiology laboratory and requires genetic testing. M. avium and Mycobacterium intracellulare are the two original members of the complex. It is a nonmotile, non-spore-forming, gram-positive acid-fast bacillus.

MAC infection is an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection, occurring predominantly at CD4+ T cell counts of <50/μL. The most common presentation is disseminated disease with fever, weight loss, and night sweats. Treatment consists of Clarithromycin / Azithromycin with Ethambutol/ Rifabutin.

Other options:

Option A: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive, capsulated, flame-shaped, or lanceolate-shaped diplococcus.

Option B: E. coli is a gram-negative, flagellated rod. It is a lactose fermenter and hence, grows on MacConkey medium to produce pink colonies.

Option D: Actinomyces are gram-positive, anaerobic, and filamentous bacteria that are non-acid-fast.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral nasal obstruction associated with watery nasal discharge and bleeding. A diagnosis of inverted papilloma is made. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Inverted papilloma is a benign and invasive tumor.

Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor or transitional cell papilloma or Schneiderian papilloma) is a benign neoplasm of the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose (also called the Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses. The lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus is the most common site of origin.

The hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into the stroma. It is common in the 4th to 7th decades of life with a male preponderance. Clinical features are unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. It is almost always unilateral. It can invade sinuses or the orbit, resulting in proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation.
 
An examination of the nose or endoscopy shows a polypoidal mass resembling simple nasal polyps. A computed tomography(CT) scan and/or magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) show the location and extent of the lesion. 
MRI is used to differentiate associated secretions in the sinus from the actual tumor mass. A biopsy is essential for diagnosis.
 
Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice, done preferably via endoscopy. Malignancy has been observed in up to 15% of the cases.

Related Pearl: Inverted Papilloma

  • Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma
  • It is the most common benign tumor of the nasal cavity
  • It is a premalignant condition with 10-15% chances of turning malignant
  • Etiology: Human papilloma virus has been implicated in its etiology
  • Origin: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose from the non-olfactory epithelium of nose
  • Clinical features:
    • More common in males
    • The age group most commonly affected is 40-70 years
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis are the main presenting symptoms
    • It is a locally invasive tumor and can invade orbit and paranasal sinuses.
    • Proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation can result from orbital invasion
  • Findings:
    • It is seen as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp
  • Investigations: A biopsy is needed for diagnosis
  • Treatment: Medial maxillectomy via lateral rhinotomy or midfacial degloving approach
  • Radiotherapy can lead to malignancy

questions.text: The nerve supply of larynx above the level of the vocal cords is by _______
questions.solution:
The nerve supply of larynx above the level of vocal cords is by internal laryngeal nerve which is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

  • Sensory innervation of the larynx above the level of vocal cords is by the internal laryngeal nerve.
  • Sensory innervation of the larynx below the level of vocal cords is by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • At the level of vocal cords, it is supplied both by the internal laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerves.

All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except for cricothyroid, which is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.
