questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Granisetron i+ dexamethasone+ aprepitant is used to treat Chemotherapy-induced Nausea and Vomiting(CINV).

The combination of 5-HT3 receptor antagonists, NK1 receptor antagonists, and dexamethasone has decreased emesis and decreased the use of rescue medications for patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy during the acute and delayed phases.

5-HT3 receptor antagonists- Drugs are ondansetron, granisetron, dolasetron, and palonosetron. These agents are believed to prevent CINV by antagonizing 5-HT3 receptors either peripherally on vagal nerve terminals and/or centrally in the chemoreceptor trigger zone. The most common adverse effects are headaches and constipation.

NK1 receptor antagonists- They inhibit substance P in peripheral and central emetic pathways. Aprepitant was the first drug in this class to be approved by the FDA. The most common adverse effects include fatigue, headache, anorexia, diarrhoea, and increased transaminases.

Corticosteroids- They are now considered a mainstay of antiemetic regimens for the prevention of acute and delayed emesis. Dexamethasone is the recommended corticosteroid according to current guidelines.

Dopamine receptor antagonists were the primary antiemetics used for CINV, before the approval of the 5-HT3 antagonists. They have serious extrapyramidal side effects like akathisia, dystonia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome. With the current availability of more effective preventive agents, dopamine receptor antagonists are mostly used in the management of breakthrough or refractory emesis.  This class includes prochlorperazine, haloperidol, droperidol, and metoclopramide.

questions.text: According to the neonatal resuscitation protocol,  below what heart rate are chest compressions initiated?
questions.solution:
According to the neonatal resuscitation protocol, chest compressions are started when heart rate is below 60/min
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the heart rate is less than 100/min, PPV is initially provided with bag and mask on room air, and SPO2 monitoring is done. Increasing concentration of oxygen is used to ensure adequate ventilation.
  • If the heart rate is below 60, chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3: 1.
  • If the heart rate still remains <60, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a vocal nodule.

Vocal nodules are also known as singer’s or screamer's nodes. It occurs at the mid-membranous portion of the vocal cords at the free edge. It is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus is subjected to maximum trauma. It presents as bilateral swellings in the vocal cords.

Vocal nodules occur due to vocal trauma when a person speaks in a loud voice for prolonged periods. They mostly affect teachers, actors, vendors, or pop singers.

Symptoms of vocal nodules are hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation.

Treatment includes educating the patient on proper use of voice. Surgery is reserved for patients who remain symptomatic despite voice therapy.

Option A: Vocal polyp is caused by sudden shouting which results in hemorrhage and edema of the vocal cord.Affected individuals present with hoarseness of voice and diplophonia(double voice). Other factors associated with it are allergy and cigarette smoking. It presents as a benign swelling on the free edge of the vocal cord. 

Option B: Vocal cysts are retention cysts due to blockage of seromucinous glands of the laryngeal mucosa. They occur in the false vocal cords.

Option D: Reinke's edema is the collection of fluid in Reinke's space. Affected individuals present with diffuse swelling of the vocal cords. Treatment involves the removal of gelatinous collection by a longitudinal incision on the vocal cord.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids

Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid

Cricothyroid

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: identify the true statement about the given dose-response curve:

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug B is more efficacious than drug A

questions.solution:
The more the curve is to the left, the more its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent on the given dose-response curve (DRC).

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • The more the curve is on the left side, the more its potency.
  • Hence in the given DRC drug B is the most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve.
  • Hence in the given DRC, drug B has the least efficacy, and drugs A, C & D are equally efficacious.

questions.text: During a vaccination drive, a male patient asks the presiding doctor if the recommended vaccine can lead to impotency. What type of barrier will the doctor be addressing?
questions.solution:
The doctor in this case is trying to address the cultural barrier.

This individual thinks that vaccination can cause impotency. This may be due to his understanding, beliefs or knowledge towards vaccination which are all part of cultural barrier.

A failure in communication between educators and the community affects health education, counselling and motivating people. They can be of the following types:

  1. Physiological barrier due to difficulties in hearing, expression
  2. Psychological barriers like emotional disturbances, neurosis, levels of intelligence, language or comprehension difficulties.
  3. Environmental barriers like noise, invisibility, congestion
  4. Cultural barriers include illiteracy, levels of knowledge and understanding, customs, beliefs, religion, attitudes, economic and social class differences, language variations, and cultural difficulties.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms does a patient with Reinke's edema classically present with?

choices.text: Dysphagia of liquids more than solids
Dysphagia of solids more than liquids

questions.solution:
Diplophonia is the classic symptom that a patient with Reinke's edema presents with. 

Diplophonia is the production of a voice of two different tones or pitch. It is a type of dysphonia. It is also seen in vocal polyp and vocal cord cysts. It is a classical sign of Reinke's edema.

Dysphonia is a term used to describe the various changes in voice quality or production. It is a symptom seen in cases where the vocal cord is affected.

Reinke’s space is a potential space underneath the epithelium of vocal cords therefore the glottis. It contains scanty subepithelial connective tissue. Oedema of the Reinke's space is commonly seen in smokers and is called Reinke’s edema/smoker’s larynx.

questions.text: Melanin is derived from which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Melanin is derived from tyrosine. 

Products derived from tyrosine:

  • Melanin
  • Catecholamines e.g epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine
  • Thyroxine

Tyrosine is a precursor of melanin, thyroxin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

  • Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxy phenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a monooxygenase that contains copper.
  • Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.
  • Formation of catecholamines: Epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are produced by the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia.
    • Tyrosine is first hydroxylated to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by tyrosine hydroxylase.
    • DOPA is decarboxylated by DOPA decarboxylase to form dopamine.
    • Dopamine is further hydroxylated to norepinephrine or noradrenaline
    • Norepinephrine is then methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to form epinephrine or adrenaline. S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor.

The series of reactions involving the production of catecholamines is shown in the image below.

  • Formation of thyroid hormones: Tyrosine residues are iodinated to form 3-mono-iodo-tyrosine (MIT) and 3,5-di-iodo-tyrosine (DIT). These are coupled to give rise to triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine (thyroxine or T4)

The derivatives of other amino acids are given in the image below.

questions.text: Which among the following is true regarding creatinine clearance?

choices.text: It is less than inulin clearance
It is more than inulin clearance

questions.solution:
The true statement is creatinine clearance is more than inulin clearance.

Creatinine is partially secreted and never reabsorbed. Clearance of creatinine (CCr) can also be used to determine GFR; since creatinine is secreted by the tubules, thus the clearance of creatinine will be slightly higher than inulin. Hence, it overestimates GFR. 

Inulin is completely filtered and never reabsorbed. Hence, it can be used for GFR estimation. 

PAH(para amino hippuric acid) at low plasma concentrations is completely filtered and secreted. Hence, it can be used for the estimation of renal blood flow.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. On examination, pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles was noted. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
History of progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties with characteristic finding of pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles points to a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). 

Dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), is absent in these patients due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene. Dystrophin connects actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma by the smaller proteins syntrophins in the cytoplasm. Lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular components.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease
  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder, and the causative gene is located at Xp21.
  • Clinical features
    • Progressive weakness with developmental delay occurs.
    • Pseudohypertrophy of calves and wasting of thigh muscles are seen.
    • Trendelenburg gait or hip waddle is characteristic.
    • Gower’s sign: Indicates weakness of proximal muscles: The patient has to use hands and arms to "walk up" their own body from a squatting position.
    • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Diagnosis
    • Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
    • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene
    • If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.
  • Treatment: Treatment of cardiac decompensation, nutritional management, physiotherapy, and glucocorticoids.
  • Prognosis: Death occurs usually at about 18 to 20 years of age due to respiratory failure, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or aspiration.

Other options:

Option A: Abnormal collagen synthesis may be seen in conditions such as Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes and osteogenesis imperfecta.

Option C: Myotonic dystrophy is caused by expansions of CTG triplet repeats in the 3′-noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene. Myotonia, a sustained involuntary contraction of muscles, is a key feature of the disease.

Option D: Marfan syndrome results from an inherited defect in an extracellular glycoprotein fibrillin-1.

questions.text: A child presents with the findings shown in the image below. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
This malnourished child with a distended abdomen has kwashiorkor due to protein malnutrition.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema and apathy. It usually affects infants and children, most often around the age of weaning till the age of 5. 

It is due to an overall deficiency in protein and calories, with a much more severe protein deficit. It is due to a deficiency of proteins, such as albumin that exerts oncotic pressure in the blood that there is such extensive pitting edema which starts in the legs, and feet and then spreads to hands, face and later becomes generalized.

Skin changes occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath forming patches of hyper and hypopigmentation called flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin gets easily infected.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. It may lose its curl. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish. Alternating bands of light and normal color hair may be seen, known as the flag sign. Children are miserable, apathetic, and often refuse to eat. There is marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

Marasmus is another form of SAM that occurs as a result of a calorie deficiency primarily. It is characterized by severe wasting that occurs due to the consumption of fat and muscle to release energy. The child has monkey facies and baggy pants appearance due to the loss of fat pad in the face and buttocks without edema.

Clinical features seen in marasmus are:

  • Head that appears large relative to the body, with staring eyes
  • Emaciated and weak appearance
  • Bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia
  • Thin, dry skin
  • Shrunken arms, thighs, and buttocks, with redundant skin folds caused by loss of subcutaneous fat
  • Thin, sparse hair that is easily plucked

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension is given the drug 'X'. Identify 'X'?
questions.solution:
Drug X is the direct renin inhibitor. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor.

Aliskiren is a nonpeptide that binds selectively to the catalytic site of renin and competitively blocks the access of angiotensinogen to this site. As a result of this, angiotensin I is not produced. 

It is recommended as an alternative antihypertensive drug for those who do not respond or do not tolerate Ist-line drugs. It can also be given in combination with ACE inhibitor/ARB(angiotensin receptor blocker) to achieve a more complete renin-angiotensin system blockade and greater BP lowering.

Option A: Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, which prevents generation of the angiotensin II.

Option B: Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist that blocks mineralocorticoid receptors.

Option D: Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes uses molecular oxygen as a hydrogen acceptor to produce water?
questions.solution:
Cytochrome C oxidase catalyzes the removal of hydrogen from a substrate using oxygen as a hydrogen acceptor and produces water as a reaction product.

Cytochrome C oxidase is a heme-containing enzyme present in many tissues. It is the terminal complex (complex IV) of the chain of respiratory carriers found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and transfers electrons from substrates to molecular oxygen, producing water as a reaction product. It can be inhibited by cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, and carbon monoxide.

Other options:

Option A: Catalase is a hemoprotein that catalyzes the breakdown of H2O2 into the water and molecular oxygen. Peroxisomes are rich in catalases.

Option B: Superoxide dismutase protects aerobic organisms by removing the superoxide anion free radicals (O2-) generated during aerobic respiration.

Option D: Pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl CoA in the mitochondria. It is a multi-enzyme complex with 5 co-enzymes and 3 apo-enzymes. The co-enzymes of pyruvate dehydrogenase are thiamine pyrophosphate(TPP), co-enzyme A, FAD, NAD+, and lipoamide.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

Related Pearl: Enzyme classification

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of hemolytic anemia?

choices.text: All of the options given below

questions.solution:
Serum haptoglobin levels are decreased in hemolytic anemias. In intravascular hemolysis, free hemoglobin released from lysed red cells is promptly bound by haptoglobin, producing a complex that is rapidly cleared by mononuclear phagocytes. In cases of extravascular hemolysis, some hemoglobin inevitably escapes from phagocytes and leads to variable decreases in plasma haptoglobin.

Hemolytic anemias are characterized by a shortened red cell life span of less than the normal 120 days. This leads to elevated erythropoietin levels and a compensatory increase in erythropoiesis which is seen as prominent reticulocytosis (OptionC) in the peripheral blood. In addition, there is an accumulation of hemoglobin degradation products produced due to hemolysis. 

 

Types of hemolysis based on location:

  • Intravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs mainly within the blood vessels
  • Extravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs via macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes

Features of intravascular hemolysis are:

  • Decreased haptoglobin
  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase 
  • Hemoglobinemia
  • Hemoglobinuria
  • Hemosiderinuria
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • Methemoglobinuria
  • Indirect hyperbilirubinemia

Features of extravascular hemolysis are:

  • Anemia
  • Splenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Variable decreases in plasma haptoglobin

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a 30-year-old male with cervical lymphadenopathy showed the following picture. The diagnosis is_____.
questions.solution:
In the picture given above, Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which is a pathognomonic feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed–Sternberg cells :

  • RS cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (thus resembling an "owl's eye" appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli.
  • The RS cell is clonal in origin and arises from the germinal center B cells but typically has lost most B-cell gene expression and function.
  • Reed Sternberg cells are not diagnostic for any condition since they are seen in many conditions such as:
    • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
    • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (commonly in immunoblastic type)
    • Infectious mononucleosis
    • Sarcomas

Hodgkin's lymphoma:

  • The patient commonly presents with palpable, firm, rubbery, non-tender lymphadenopathy in the cervical or supraclavicular region. Systemic symptoms that are classified as B symptoms including Hodgkin's lymphoma are persistent fever (>100.4ºF), drenching night sweats, and unexplained weight loss of >10% body weight over the past 6 months.
  • It is characterized by a variable number of RS cells surrounded by an inflammatory infiltrate of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils in different proportions, depending on the HL histologic subtype.
  • The interaction between the RS cell and these background inflammatory cells with their associated cytokine release is important in the development and progression of HL.

Option A: A peripheral blood smear showing numerous Auer rods in the cytoplasm of progranulocytes is characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). There is also the presence of bilobed nuclei and multiple coarse azurophilic granules. 

Option C: Histopathology of human papillomavirus lesion shows koilocytes, perinuclear halo, multinucleation, and acanthosis. 

Option D: In chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) the peripheral smear contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

Variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

  • Lacunar Variant: Nodular Sclerosis
  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to cause Beriberi?
questions.solution:
Vegan diet is least likely to cause Berberi.

Beriberi is caused due to prolonged thiamine deficiency. Primary food sources of thiamine/Vitamin B1 include yeast, organ meats, whole grains (aleurone layer), legumes, beef, and nuts. Thiamine is partially destroyed by heat.

Thiamine deficiency is more common due to chronic alcohol intake, chronic illnesses like cancer, chronic diuretic use, patients who have had bariatric surgery, and prolonged hyperemesis gravidarum. Other causes of thiamine deficiency include people on the polished rice-based diet and certain food that inactivates thiamine such as shellfish, coffee, tea, and betel nuts.

Prolonged thiamine deficiency can manifest as

  • Wet beriberi presents with an enlarged heart, tachycardia, high-output congestive heart failure, peripheral edema, and peripheral neuritis.
  • Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy occurs due to thiamine deficiency in chronic alcoholics and it manifests as horizontal nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, cerebellar ataxia, and mental impairment. When there is an additional loss of memory and a confabulatory psychosis, the syndrome is known as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following is most beneficial in the prevention of coronary artery diseases?
questions.solution:
ω3 fatty acids such as α-linolenic(ALA), eicosapentaenoic(EPA), and docosahexaenoic acids(DHA) are most beneficial in the prevention of coronary artery diseases. 

Plant oils (flaxseed, canola), fish oils, and algal oils are rich sources of ω3 fatty acids and they have anti-inflammatory effects perhaps due to their promotion of the synthesis of less inflammatory prostaglandins and leukotrienes as compared to ω6 fatty acids.

ω3 fatty acids suppress cardiac arrhythmias, reduce plasma triacylglycerol, decrease the tendency for thrombosis, lower blood pressure, and substantially reduce the risk of cardiovascular mortality and also beneficial for other chronic degenerative diseases such as cancer, rheumatoid arthritis, and Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: What is the denominator in infant mortality rate?
questions.solution:
The denominator in the infant mortality rate (IMR) is 1000 live births.

Infant mortality rate is the ratio of deaths under 1 year of age in a given year to the total number of live births in the same year usually expressed as a rate per 1000 live births.

Related Pearl: Demographic Aspects of India

  • India currently ranks 2nd in the list of countries with the highest population
  • Almost 34.5% of India’s population is urban
  • The population growth rate was 1%

SRS Statistical Report (2019-2021)

Vital statistics according to the Sample Registration System data released by the Registrar General of India:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) in India - 30 per 1000 live births
  • The crude birth rate (CBR) - 19.7
  • The crude death rate (CDR) was 6.0

questions.text: School health service should include all the following except
questions.solution:
School health service includes all the above except the presence of a doctor on school premises.

School health service programs function to promote positive health, prevent diseases, diagnose, treat and follow up on defects.

The health appraisal services of the program are administered by doctors in PHCs. Teachers are trained to do daily inspection, first aid and emergency care whenever necessary and a doctor's presence on school premises is not required.

The main aspects of this program includes:

  • Screening of general health assessment of anaemia/nutritional status, visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up, physical disabilities, learning disorders, behaviour problems, etc.
  • Prevention of communicable diseases through immunization
  • Providing a healthful school environment
  • Nutritional services
  • First-aid and emergency care
  • Education of handicapped children
  • Health education
  • Maintenance and use of school health records

questions.text: A female patient comes with complaints of swelling and pain in her great toe. Her uric acid level is found to be high. A drug which reduces uric acid levels is prescribed. Which of the following enzyme should the drug inhibit?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is a purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme.

Allopurinol is used to treat hyperuricemia in patients with gout. It also prevents the occurrence of gout in those with haematological malignancies about to undergo chemotherapy.

Allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine), reduce urate production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. This prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine, and xanthine to uric acid, thereby reducing plasma uric acid levels. Allopurinol is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase. 

Febuxostat is a nonpurine inhibitor of uric acid synthesis. It is not an analogue of hypoxanthine. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase and it is indicated in gout management. 

Other options:

Option A: Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor (urease generates ammonia from urea that elevates the pH of the urine that can lead to formation of triple phosphate stones).

Option B: Alkaptonuria is a disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate.

Option C: Menkes disease is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was prescribed a diuretic by a doctor for the management of hypertension. Which of the following diuretic acts on the site 'A' marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The site 'A' in the given image represents a distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide, thiazide type of diuretuic act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). 

They block the Na+/Cl- symport in the DCT leading to an increase in Na+ and Cl− excretion. Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension. They are also used for the treatment of edema associated with congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, and acute glomerulonephritis.

The advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost

The adverse effects include extracellular volume depletion, hypotension, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia.

Other options:

Option A: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits Na+-K+-2Cl– symport. They are used in acute pulmonary edema, edema associated with congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, and nephrotic syndrome.

Option C: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and primarily acts in the proximal tubule. It is used in glaucoma, altitude sickness, diuretic resistance, and metabolic alkalosis.

Option D: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that acts primarily in the loop of Henle. It also acts in the proximal tubule. It is used in elevated intraocular pressure and elevated intracranial pressure.

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with a throbbing unilateral headache and nodular thickening along the temporal artery. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of giant cells and granuloma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of giant cell arteritis.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the temporal arteries. It is seen in people over 50 years of age. It usually presents with facial pain or headache along the course of the superficial temporal artery.

It may be associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have temporal artery abnormalities such as enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and loss of pulse of the temporal artery, either unilateral or bilateral. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. 

It can also affect:

  • The ophthalmic arteries- leading to sudden onset diplopia or blindness
  • The aorta- leading to giant-cell aortitis
  • The vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. Therefore, patients with a clinical diagnosis of GCA, especially with headaches or visual symptoms, should be started on steroids immediately.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with increased cough, increased breathlessness, and decreased exercise capacity. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary fibrosis. Which drug can be administered in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Of the given options Pirfenidone is used in the condition of pulmonary fibrosis.

Pirfenidone is a novel anti-fibrotic agent approved for treating Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) in humans for patients with mild to moderate disease. It inhibits the progression of fibrosis and loss of lung function in patients with IPF via its antifibrotic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties. 

Pirfenidone inhibits growth factors involved in connective tissue proliferation and is also approved for use in acute exacerbations of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Bortezomib is a first-generation inhibitor of proteasome-mediated protein degradation that has a role in the treatment of multiple myeloma.

Option B: Roflumilast is a phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitor used in severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder(COPD).

Option C: Imatinib is used as a targeted treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia by targeting the BCR-ABL Tyrosine kinase fusion protein.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve can be injured, when a fracture is sustained at the area marked with the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
In the given image the arrow points to the medial epicondyle. Fracture at the medial epicondyle damages the ulnar nerve. 

The nerves related to the humerus are:

  • Axillary nerve is at the surgical neck 
  • Ulnar nerve is at the medial epicondyle
  • Radial nerve is at the spiral groove of the shaft of the humerus. 

Ulnar nerve branches and supply: 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin that principally attacks the joints, producing nonsuppurative, proliferative, and inflammatory synovitis. The inflammation progresses to the destruction of the articular cartilage and ankylosis of the joints.

In RA, the synovium contains germinal centers with secondary follicles and abundant plasma cells, which produce antibodies, some are autoantibodies. Many of the autoantibodies produced in the lymphoid organs are specific for citrullinated peptides (CCPs). 80% of patients have serum IgM or IgA autoantibodies that bind to the Fc portions of their own IgG. These autoantibodies are called rheumatoid factor and may also be deposited in joints as immune complexes.

The characteristic histologic features of RA include:

  • Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation
  • Dense inflammatory infiltrates
  • Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis
  • Fibrinopurulent exudate on the synovial and joint surfaces
  • Osteoclastic activity in the underlying bone
  • Subcutaneous nodule: necrotizing granulomas with a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded activated macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells                       

This all together leads to a mass of edematous synovium called pannus, which grows over the articular cartilage and causes its erosion.

questions.text: A patient on anti-cancer therapy developed an infection. Blood analysis revealed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Filgrastim is the drug used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced neutropenia.

Filgrastim is a recombinant human G-CSF(granulocyte-colony stimulating factor), that stimulates CFU-G(colony-forming unit- granulocyte) to increase neutrophil production. It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion. It is indicated in: 

  • The treatment of severe neutropenia after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and high-dose cancer chemotherapy.
  • The treatment of severe congenital neutropenias.
  • The treatment of neutropenia of patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine.

Important adverse reactions include bone pain, local skin reaction, and cutaneous necrotizing vasculitis.

Other options:

Option A: Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the management of immune thrombocytopenic purpura(ITP). 

Option B: Oprelvekin is a recombinant human IL-11. It stimulates hematopoiesis. It is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia due to non-myeloid malignancies. Important adverse effects are fluid retention, tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath.

Option D: Epoetin alfa is a recombinant human erythropoietin analogue that stimulates red blood cell production. It is used in the treatment of anaemias associated with surgery, chronic kidney disease, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, prematurity, and certain chronic inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with sudden onset of high-grade fever, seizures,  and loss of consciousness. On examination, the child had anaemia, hypoglycemia, and no neurological deficits. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
This scenario depicts a case of cerebral malaria due to a severe complicated falciparum infection.

Severe complicated malaria is caused by Plasmodium falciparum and is characterized by jaundice, severe anaemia, respiratory distress, bleeding manifestation, cardiovascular collapse, renal failure and cerebral malaria.

Cerebral malaria is diagnosed in the case of P. falciparum parasitemia with altered consciousness. Common features include seizures and hypoglycemia. Retinal haemorrhages, neurological findings like hemiplegia, absent or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and a positive Babinski sign can also be seen.

All patients with severe malaria should be treated with intravenous or intramuscular artesunate for at least 24 hours.

Meningitis has fever accompanied by lethargy, irritability, signs of meningeal irritation like the Kernig sign-flexion of the hip 90 degrees with subsequent pain with extension of the leg, and Brudzinski sign-involuntary flexion of the knees and hips after passive flexion of the neck while supine. Increased ICP is suggested by headache, emesis, bulging fontanel or widening of the sutures, oculomotor (anisocoria, ptosis) or abducens nerve paralysis, hypertension with bradycardia, apnea or hyperventilation, stupor, coma, or signs of herniation. A lumbar puncture is essential to obtain CSF for Gram stain and culture, which is the most important step in the diagnosis of meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the foramen marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The marked arrow indicates the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm. Out of the given options, the thoracic duct passes through it.

The diaphragm has several openings through which structures can pass between the thorax and abdomen. There are three large openings and several smaller openings. The large openings are the aortic hiatus, the esophageal hiatus, and the caval hiatus.

The aortic opening is the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening. It is found at the level of the lower border of the twelfth thoracic vertebra and the corresponding intervertebral disc. It is bounded by the diaphragmatic crura laterally, vertebral column posteriorly, and the median arcuate ligament anteriorly. 

Structures passing through the aortic opening are:

  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
  • Hemiazygous vein

questions.text: A cattle farmer presented with a lesion on the arm. Gram staining showed gram-positive rods with square ends with a central spore. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive rod with square ends giving it a characteristic box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive, endospore-forming (non-bulging spores), rod-shaped bacterium. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule.

The image shows the characteristic box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance of bacillus anthracis on Gram staining.

Bacillus anthracis is a category A bioterrorism agent which can cause:

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is caused by contact with infected animal/ animal products. It is seen in tanners and hide-porters. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops in about 1–7 days. This develops into a vesicle that later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a malignant pustule. The majority of the patients recover spontaneously, but a few may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax: It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis and sepsis. 
  • Intestinal anthrax: It is caused rarely, by ingesting infected animals. 

The image below shows necrotic eschar seen in anthrax:

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Microscopy of the smears shows bacilli arranged end to end in the form of long chains. This is called bamboo stick appearance.
  • Under the low-power microscope, the edge of the colony is composed of long, interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling locks of matted hair, called Medusa head appearance.

Fluid or pus from cutaneous lesions, pleural fluid, blood, or CSF can be cultured on:

  • Nutrient agar- frosted glass appearance
  • Gelatin stab culture- Inverted fir tree appearance
  • Blood agar- Non-hemolytic colonies
  • Solid medium with penicillin- String of pearls appearance

Other options:

Option A: Infection with Bacillus cereus causes food poisoning with a longer incubation period of 8-16 hours. But patients usually have a history of consumption of fried rice.

Option C: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Burns infections
  • Opportunistic and nosocomial infections
  • Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum
  • Green-nail syndrome

Option D: Brucellosis is a zoonotic infection transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products from goats, sheep, cattle, pigs, and other animals. Clinically, patients may present with an acute infection comprised of undulant fever (Rising and falling fever). They may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following hepatitis viruses is likely to get transmitted via feco-oral route?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis A has feco-oral transmission. Transmission of Hepatitis B, C, and D can occur sexually.

questions.text: The ideal per capita space for students in a classroom should be
questions.solution:
Per capita space for students in classroom should be >10 sq. ft.

Healthful school environment includes

  • Location: Properly approachable roads and away from noisy surroundings
  • Site: 5 acres for primary schools; 10 acres for higher elementary schools.
  • Structure: Exterior walls 10 inch thick and heat resistant.
  • Class room: 1 class room per 40 students maximum; Per capita space > 10 sq. feet
  • Furniture: Minus type with proper back-rests.
  • Doors and windows: Doors and windows area> 25% of floor area
  • Color: Inside color of walls should be white.
  • Lighting: Natural light,from sides and not from the front.
  • Water supply: Safe and potable and continuous supply through taps.
  • Lavatory: 1 urinal per 60 students and 1 latrine per 100 students.

questions.text: The most appropriate description of vasomotor reversal of Dale is

choices.text: Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure
A patient pretreated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on administration of adrenaline.
High dose of acetylcholine after pretreatment with atropine produces increase in blood pressure and heart rate
Increase in pulse pressure is produced by intravenous administration of isoprenaline

questions.solution:
A patient pretreated with phentolamine develops severe hypotension on the administration of adrenaline is the most appropriate description of the vasomotor reversal of Dale. (Option B)

Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.

Normally, a high dose of epinephrine injected produces α1 mediated rise in BP followed by β2 mediated fall in BP.

Vasomotor reversal of Dale: Administration of adrenaline after administration of α blockers(phentolamine) produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β-mediated response is seen, i.e., a fall in BP.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is a cauliflower-like growth in the left eye along with leukocoria and an absent red reflex. The microscopic appearance of the specimen shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which is the causative gene in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and histology point toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma which occurs due to a mutation in the Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Present within the first two years of life
  • Leukocoria 
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis.
  • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases.
  • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain is the investigation of choice.

 The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy. Enucleation is done when: 

  • Tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • Optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues resulting in marked proptosis. Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

Other options:

Option B: COL5A1 mutation affects type 5 collagen. This mutation is seen in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Option C: Retinitis pigmentosa occurs due to inherited or acquired mutations in the rhodopsin gene. 

Option D: NOTCH1 is the most commonly affected gene in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match for ABCD according to paediatrics advanced life support?
questions.solution:
According to paediatrics advanced life support (PALS), the incorrectly matched one is D-dehydration.

The American Heart Association, in its Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) curriculum, supports the structured format of the airway, breathing, circulation, disability, and exposure- ABCDE for primary assessment.

Airway- The primary survey's first and most important portion is the patient’s airway. A simple chin-lift or jaw thrust manoeuvre re-aligns the airway. An artificial airway that is appropriate for the patient’s situation like oropharyngeal airways (OPA), and nasopharyngeal airways (NPA) can be used.

Breathing-Assessment of breathing includes respiratory rate, effort, abnormal sounds, and pulse oximetry. Central cyanosis is a sign of severe hypoxia and indicates an emergent need for oxygen supplementation and respiratory support.

Circulation- Cardiovascular function is assessed by evaluation of skin colour and temperature, heart rate, heart rhythm, pulses, and capillary refill time.

Disability- This refers to a child’s neurologic function in terms of the level of consciousness. An assessment of light reflex and use of either of the standard scores used in paediatrics. Any child with a depressed level of consciousness should be immediately assessed for abnormalities in cardiorespiratory status.

Exposure- Exposure is the final component after the child has been stabilized. This includes exposing the child to assess for previously unidentified injuries by performing a focused physical exam, and assessing for burns, bruising, bleeding, joint laxity, and fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol?

choices.text: Directly acts as arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect tachycardia
Blocks both alpha1 and beta adrenergic receptors
Primarily acts as venodilator with little effect on arterioles
Decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as relaxant vascular smooth muscles

questions.solution:
Option B is the correct statement regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol.

Labetalol acts as a competitive antagonist at both alpha-1 and beta-adrenergic receptors. α1 receptor blockade leads to the relaxation of arterial smooth muscle and leads to vasodilation, particularly when the patient is upright. The β1 blockade also contributes to a fall in blood pressure as it blocks reflex sympathetic stimulation of the heart.

Labetalol is available in oral form for the treatment of chronic hypertension and as an intravenous formulation for use in hypertensive emergencies. It can be used in the setting of a pregnancy-induced hypertensive crisis

questions.text: A 34-year-old male whose staple diet primarily consisted of only maize presents with diarrhea, dementia, and photosensitive dermatitis in sun-exposed areas. Which vitamin is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Maize contains niacin in bound form and is unavailable for absorption. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

Casal’s necklace pattern classically seen in pellagra is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar.

Pellagra occurs despite an adequate intake of tryptophan & niacin in the case of

  • Carcinoid syndrome as tryptophan will be used up in the production of serotonin 
  • Hartnup disease due to a defect in the tryptophan transporter resulting in intestinal malabsorption and failure of renal reabsorption.

Niacin significantly decreases concentrations of all apoB-containing lipoproteins like VLDL, IDL, LDL, and lipoprotein a. It also increases HDL cholesterol.

Niacin toxicity occurs when it is taken in excess quantity for the treatment of hyperlipidemia and manifests as

  • Prostaglandin-mediated cutaneous flushing
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Fulminant hepatitis (the most serious complication)
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Macular edema and macular cysts

questions.text: Which drug elicits the following response on blood pressure and heart rate as shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows an increase in systolic pressure, diastolic pressure and mean arterial pressure, and reflex bradycardia. This effect is seen in case of norepinephrine.

Norepinephrine acts on α1 and β1 receptors to increase the peripheral vascular resistance and stroke volume respectively. This causes an increase in diastolic, systolic, and mean arterial pressure. Increased mean arterial pressure leads to reflex bradycardia.

Adrenergic drug

Receptors it acts on

Adrenaline

α1 + α2 +β1 + β2 

Noradrenaline

α1 +α2 +β1 but no β2 action

Isoproterenol

β1 + β2 + β3 but no α action

Other options:

Option B: Isoproterenol increases systolic blood pressure by increasing contractility and increases heart rate due to its β1 action. The β2-mediated vasodilation, results in a decrease in mean arterial pressure and reflex tachycardia.

Option C: On administration of epinephrine, there is an increase in systolic pressure which is greater than the decrease in diastolic pressure so the pulse pressure increases. Heart rate is increased as a result of direct cardiac stimulation.
At higher concentrations of adrenaline with IV administration, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen. Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the β2 action predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen. This is referred to as the biphasic reaction of epinephrine.

Option D: At higher concentration, dopamine usually increases systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure and has no effect on diastolic blood pressure or increases it slightly. Tachycardia is less prominent during the infusion of dopamine.

questions.text: The stain used for identifying Cryptococcus is _____
questions.solution:
The stain used for identifying Cryptococcus is India ink stain.

Indian ink is a negative staining method that provides a uniformly coloured background. The unstained organisms stand out in contrast to the background. It is useful in the demonstration of organisms with capsules that do not take simple stains. It is also used to stain slender bacteria like spirochetes.

The India ink preparation is employed to detect the presence of Cryptococcus neoformans. It is seen as a globular, encapsulated yeast cell with or without budding, between 5 to 20 μm in diameter in size. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is seen against a black background.

Cryptococcus can be cultured from biologic samples like the CSF, sputum, and skin biopsy on routine fungal and bacterial culture media. Colonies are opaque, white-to-cream coloured, and may turn orange-tan or brown after prolonged incubation. They have a mucoid appearance due to the presence of the capsule around the yeast cells.

The image below shows the fungus Cryptococcus, stained with Indian ink.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For Cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles in the external auditory meatus and over the tympanic membrane. In addition to that, he also has facial nerve palsy. What is the most likely diagnosis and which is the site that is affected?

choices.text: Ramsay Hunt syndrome and basal ganglion
Ramsay Hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion is affected. 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also called herpes zoster oticus, is a late complication of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection, that results in inflammation of the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).

The causative agent, the varicella-zoster virus, is a double-stranded DNA virus. Clinical features are facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna. Intense pain around the ear in addition to the vesicles also occurs. There may also be anesthesia of the face, giddiness, and hearing impairment due to the involvement of the Vth and VIIIth nerves.

It is characterized by a classic triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, otalgia, and vesicles in the auditory canal or on the auricle.

The illustration given below shows the clinical features seen in Ramsay Hunt syndrome.

The treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome involves antiviral medications like acyclovir or famciclovir, as well as corticosteroids like prednisone.

Melkersson syndrome presents with a triad of facial paralysis, swelling of the face and lips, and furrows in the tongue.

questions.text: A psychiatrist prescribes lithium for a patient who is diagnosed with bipolar disorder. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding lithium?

choices.text: Lithium is teratogenic if given to pregnant females
Lithium toxicity is exacerbated with thiazide
Lithium can decrease thyroid hormone levels
Hemodialysis is not useful in lithium overdose

questions.solution:
Option D is the incorrect statement regarding lithium. Hemodialysis is used in lithium overdose.

Lithium is a small monovalent cation. It is used in the treatment of acute mania and the prevention of recurrences of bipolar disorder in adults or adolescents. Lithium is a mood stabilizer with suicide reduction in bipolar patients and is also efficacious in unipolar depressive patients who respond inadequately to antidepressant therapy

Lithium toxicity occurs with the concomitant use of 

  1. Thiazide diuretics (chlorthalidone)- Diuretics causees Na+ loss which promotes proximal tubular reabsorption of Na+ as well as Li+. Hence, plasma levels of lithium rise. (Option B)
  2. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
  3. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  4. Tetracyclines 
  5. Loop diuretics (furosemide)

These act by increasing the tubular reabsorption of lithium, resulting in decreased excretion of lithium and thereby increasing the serum lithium levels, causing toxicity.

Adverse effects-Serum lithium levels greater than 1.5 mEq/L are considered toxic.

  • Acute intoxication is characterized by vomiting, profuse diarrhea, coarse tremor, ataxia, dysarthria, and convulsions.
  • Central nervous system: Lithium at therapeutic levels causes fine tremors and at toxic levels causes coarse tremors. Incoordination, ataxia, and slurred speech can occur at peak serum concentrations.
  • On long-term use, some patients develop renal diabetes insipidus. Patients present with polyuria and polydipsia. 
  • Lithium therapy causes significant weight gain.
  • Lithium therapy is associated with hypothyroidism. This is due to interference with the release of thyroid hormone which leads to falling in circulating T3, and T4 levels and a subsequent increase in TSH secretion from pituitary enlargement and stimulation of the thyroid. (Option C)
  • Lithium is contraindicated in pregnancy. Early pregnancy causes Ebstein anomaly in the fetus. Fetal lithium exposure is associated with neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and cardiac murmur. (Option A)

Treatment of lithium overdose- There is no specific antidote. Osmotic diuretics and sodium bicarbonate infusion promote lithium excretion. Haemodialysis is indicated if serum levels are > 4 mEq/L.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A surveyor visits a household consisting of a 35-year-old man, his wife who is 6 weeks pregnant and a 3-year-old child. The man's brother along with his wife is currently visiting them for a month owing to winter vacation. What type of family would the surveyor classify the household?
questions.solution:
A surveyor would label this house as a nuclear family.

The nuclear or elementary family consists of the married couple and their children while they are still regarded as dependents. This nuclear family has visitors who neither live permanantly in the same household or hold a common property which are characters of a joint or extended family.

The joint or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household and hold the property in common. The senior male member of the family is considered as the head.

Third generation family consists of three generations that are direct descents, living in the same house. It occurs usually when young couples continue to live with their parents and have their own children.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatiguability which improves with neostigmine. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial nerve junctions are affected leading to weakness in the lids and extraocular muscles causing diplopia, ptosis in the early stages. Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling, weakness in chewing and swallowing, speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of the palate and tongue.
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • The repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium and neostigmine are acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission. The same effect is seen with 

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine.
  • Thymectomy.
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. Neostigmine has no effect on it.

Option C: ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. The pathologic hallmark of ALS includes the involvement of lower motor neurons of the ventral/ anterior horn of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles, and the afferent corticospinal upper motor neurons in layer five of the motor cortex. Neostigmine has no effect on it.

Option D: The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO).Neostigmine has no effect on it.

questions.text: A new resident to a high-altitude area develops hypoxia. What is the causative factor?
questions.solution:
Hypoxia in high altitude is due to the low partial pressure of O2.

Adaptation at High Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and is directly proportional to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis. This raised pH inhibits the brain stem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration, bringing the pH to normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: A patient presents with thick nasal discharge and headache. Examination reveals hypertrophy of the inferior turbinate with a mulberry appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of hypertrophic rhinitis.

It is characterized by the thickening of the mucosa, submucosa, seromucous glands, periosteum, and bone. 

Recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis, chronic irritation of nasal mucosa due to smoking, prolonged use of nasal drops, vasomotor and allergic rhinitis, and industrial irritants are some of the causes of hypertrophic rhinitis.

Clinical features are thick and sticky nasal discharge, headache, and transient anosmia. Examination reveals hypertrophy of the turbinates with underlying fibrosis. Mulberry hypertrophy is seen in hypertrophic rhinitis. Maximum changes are seen in the inferior turbinate.

Treatment includes cryosurgery of turbinates, linear cauterisation, submucosal diathermy, partial or total turbinectomy and lasers.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation of choice: Nasal endoscopy. Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: In relation to which wall of the orbit is the canaliculi that opens into the lacrimal sac present?
questions.solution:
The canaliculi that open into the lacrimal sac are present in relation to the medial wall of the orbit.

Anatomy

The lacrimal drainage system consists of the following structures:

  • The puncta are openings on the lid margin.
  • Each canaliculus (superior and inferior) has two parts: 
    • Vertical (2 mm)
    • Horizontal (8 mm)
  • The superior and inferior canaliculi usually unite to form the common canaliculus, which opens into the lateral wall of the lacrimal sac.
  • A small flap of mucosa (Rosenmüller valve) overhangs the junction of the common canaliculus and the lacrimal sac and prevents the reflux of tears into the canaliculi.
  • The lacrimal sac is 10–12 mm long and lies in the lacrimal fossa. The lacrimal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla separate the lacrimal sac from the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.
  • The nasolacrimal duct is 12–18 mm long and is directed downwards, backward, and laterally.

 Image: Lacrimal apparatus

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is the principal constituent of serum osmolality?
questions.solution:
The principal constituent of serum osmolality is sodium.

Serum osmolality = 2 sodium + (glucose/18) + (BUN/2.8).

The principal determinants of the osmolality of serum are the concentrations of sodium, glucose and urea (blood urea nitrogen or BUN).

Osmolality is defined as a measure of the osmoles (Osm) of solute per kilogram of solvent (osmol/kg or Osm/kg). The osmolality of the intracellular and extracellular fluids is maintained between 290 and 310 mOsm in each compartment.

An increase in plasma sodium (plasma osmolality) attracts water out of the cell. This leads to shrinkage of the intracellular volume. Hyponatremia (decreased plasma osmolality) allows the flow of water into the cell and expands intracellular volume.

Related Pearl: Extracellular fluid vs Intracellular fluid

questions.text: A patient presents with a cyst on the neck anterior to the sternocleidomastoid at the junction of the upper and middle third of the muscle. This cyst is due to the persistence of which of the following embryological clefts?
questions.solution:
A cyst presenting at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border is most likely a branchial cyst. It develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft.

Branchial cyst is most commonly seen at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border. It is usually lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate to a lesser extent when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

questions.text: A child who has overdosed on iron tablets comes with nausea and abdominal pain. What is the antidote for this toxicity?
questions.solution:
The antidote used for iron overdose is deferoxamine.

Deferoxamine, a potent iron-chelating compound, can be given intravenously to bind iron that has already been absorbed and to promote its excretion in urine and faeces. Hypotension is a common side effect of deferoxamine infusion. The deferoxamine-iron complex can colour the urine reddish.

Iron toxicity presents as profuse vomiting and diarrhoea (often bloody), abdominal pain, and significant volume losses. Later patients develop multisystem organ failure, shock, and metabolic acidosis.
