questions.text: Which among the following parasites directly invade the skin?
questions.solution:
The parasite that directly invades the skin is Schistosoma mansoni.

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria. Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self-limiting.

After 4- 8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes which result in a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, and hepatosplenomegaly.

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and blood dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis. The drug of choice is praziquantel 40mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose.

A yellowish-brown egg with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end is suggestive of Schistosoma mansoni. In Schistosoma hematobium, the egg has a terminal spine. In Schistosoma japonicum, the egg has no spine but shows a lateral small rudimentary knob.

The life cycle of schistosomes is represented below:

Other options:

Option B: Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinenesis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harboring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

Option C: Wuchereria bancrofti causes filariasis. The adult worms block the lymphatic vessels leading to inflammation and granuloma formation. This causes hard pitting or brawny edema. It can present as lymphadenitis, lymphedema, hydrocele, and elephantiasis. The disease spreads from person to person through mosquito bites.

Option D: Onchocerca volvulus is a tissue nematode. The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host. During a blood meal, the female blackfly ingests the microfilariae from the skin and lymphatics of an infected person. Within the vector, the microfilariae develop into the infective stage. When the infected black fly bites another person, it introduces third-stage filarial larvae into the skin of the human host.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Highest birth rate is seen in which stage of the demographic cycle?
questions.solution:
The highest birth rate is seen in stage I of the demographic cycle.

Demographic cycle of a country represents a population’s shift from high mortality and high fertility to low mortality and low fertility.

 

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 68-year-old  female patient has had a diabetic cataract for the past 3 months. Accumulation of which of the following substances is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
A diabetic cataract occurs due to the accumulation of sorbitol and fructose within the lens.

In diabetic patients, increased levels of blood glucose lead to high levels of glucose in the aqueous humor. The excess glucose in the aqueous humor is metabolized into sorbitol through the polyol pathway by the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol is then converted to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase but at a much slower rate. In addition, the polar nature of sorbitol prevents its intracellular removal through diffusion.

Sorbitol and fructose accumulate in the lens and the osmotic stress so produced results in overhydration, hydropic lens fibers, and apoptosis of the lens epithelial cells. Thus, the secondary osmotic overhydration is responsible for cortical opacities in a distinct pattern causing snowflake cataracts as shown below.

 

Related Pearl: Diseases and Associated Cataracts - Images

Wilson's Disease/Chalcosis: Sunflower Cataract

Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract

Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract

Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the clinic by her mother with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months and vesicles in the superficial layer of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of myringitis bullosa.

Bullous myringitis (myringitis bullosa haemorrhagica) is the finding of vesicles in the superficial layer of the tympanic membrane without affecting the contents of the external or middle ear. If the middle ear becomes involved, this would be consistent with acute otitis media. It occurs due to infection by influenza virus or by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Bloody otorrhea can occur when a bulla rupture and is referred to as bullous hemorrhagic myringitis.

Option B: Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. Mild earaches with a history of upper respiratory tract infection are usually seen. 

On otoscopy, 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • If the tympanic membrane is transparent fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen

 The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques. 
  • Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

Option C: Acute otitis media is an acute infection of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. It presents with marked earache and hearing loss is seen in later stages. Otoscopy shows a red and bulging tympanic membrane. 

 

Option D: Myringitis granulosa is characterized by granulations on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane. It is associated with long-standing foreign body, wax impaction, and external ear infection.

questions.text:
A patient comes with a history of category 3 dog bites. He received prophylaxis for a monkey bite 6 months back. What is the next step in management?

RIG- Rabies immunoglobulin

choices.text: Wound cleaning+ rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3

questions.solution:
This patient should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 as he has received a prior course of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago.

In India, monkeys are known to transmit rabies. Hence the national rabies control program advises a full course of PEP for monkey bites. This patient who was bitten by a monkey 6 months back would have received PEP for rabies. 

Management of a new dog bite in a previously immunized individual with either pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is as follows:

  • Category I: Wound treatment only
  • Category II/ III:
    • Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 min and apply antiseptic
    • Receive Anti-rabies vaccine (ARV) 2 doses ID (0.1 ml, 1 site)/ 2 doses IM (1 VIAL, 1 site) on days 0 and 3.

Rabies immunoglobulin is not given for any category in case they have completed a full course of PEP.

*Note: In developing countries like India, the vaccination status of animals alone, doesn't play a significant role in determining the initiation of prophylaxis in humans.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of two intramuscular (IM) or two intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0 and 3.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: The given inclusion bodies are characteristic of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows intranuclear basophilic inclusions surrounded by a clear halo suggestive of owl’s eye inclusion bodies are characteristically seen in CMV infection.

 

Option A: Histopathology of human papillomavirus lesion shows koilocytes, perinuclear halo, multinucleation, and acanthosis. The following image shows pap staining showing koilocytes.

Option C: Ebstein Barr virus infection is characterized by the presence of atypical lymphocytes in the peripheral smear. The image shows atypical lymphocytes, also called Downey Type 2 cells which are CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.

Option D: Herpes simplex virus-infected cells contain large, pink to purple intranuclear inclusions known as Cowdry type A inclusions. The light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo are shown below.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with a history of edema of the face which later progressed to generalised edema. Urine showed massive proteinuria and light microscopy was normal. Electron microscopy showed effacement of podocyte foot processes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case of nephrotic syndrome shows effacement of the podocyte foot processes which is characteristic of minimal change disease (MCD).

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, oedema, hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral oedema.

A renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome. Light microscopy shows normal glomeruli and electron microscopy shows effacement of podocyte foot processes.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 60 mg/m2/day for 6 weeks, followed by a single dose of 40 mg/m2 on alternate days for the next 6 weeks is the standard treatment.

questions.text: A family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
The pedigree chart given is suggestive of an autosomal dominant inheritance. Such an inheritance has a vertical pattern in pedigree charts where individuals of each generation are affected (parents and children). Males and females are equally affected and each affected individual has a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to their offspring.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

According to the above flowchart:

Step 1: All affected individuals have an affected parent. Since multiple generations are affected it is a dominant inheritance pattern.

Step 2: Male-to-male transmission is present. The disorder thus has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

Pedigree charts of different inheritance patterns are given in the pearl below.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: In the liver, the Apo-B gene is completely translated to ApoB-100 and in the intestine, it is translated to ApoB-48. Which of the following mechanism explains this?
questions.solution:
The production of apolipoprotein (ApoB-48) in the intestine and ApoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine.

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification. As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA (stop codon) at a single specific site. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by post-transcriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The image below shows the RNA editing in the Apo-B gene.

 

DNA rearrangement, alternate splicing, and RNA interference also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of imbalance, numbness of the foot, and muscle weakness. On history taking, he revealed that he has been taking multivitamin tablets more than the prescribed dose for 1 year. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the associated symptoms seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette points towards the diagnosis of vitamin B6 toxicity due to excess intake of vitamin B6 supplements.

The active form of vitamin B6/pyridoxine is pyridoxal phosphate(PLP). PLP acts as a coenzyme for many reactions such as transaminations, decarboxylations, metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids, heme synthesis, niacin synthesis, and glycogenolysis.

Drugs that decrease pyridoxine levels include isoniazid, cycloserine,oral contraceptives, and alcohol. Deficiency manifestations of vitamin B6 include convulsions, peripheral neuritis, pellagra due to decreased niacin synthesis, and hypochromic microcytic anemia due to inhibition of heme synthesis. Vitamin B6 levels can be measured by erythrocyte transaminase assay.

Excessive intake of food-based sources of pyridoxine doesn’t cause toxicity, the only source of pyridoxine toxicity is from the intake of supratherapeutic dosing of supplements more than 100-200mg/day or iatrogenic. Pyridoxine toxicity manifests as neurological symptoms including numbness, tingling sensation, muscle weakness, and difficulty in ambulation in severe cases.

Other options:

Option A: Intake of vitamin D of more than 10,000 units per day can cause toxicity and it manifests as weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension, weight loss, and metastatic calcification(calcinosis).

Option C: 

Clinical features of Vitamin C toxicity:

  • Abdominal pain, diarrhoea, nausea
  • Increased prevalence of kidney stones (oxalate)
  • Iron overload (in patients on supplement iron)
  • Hemolysis (G6PD deficiency)

Option D: Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.

questions.text: Which of the following is an orexigenic hormone?
questions.solution:
Ghrelin is an orexigenic hormone that increases appetite.

Ghrelin is produced by the oxyntic gland area of the stomach and is primarily involved in the central control of food intake. It is also secreted by the pancreas and adrenal glands.

Functions

  • Increases appetite/food intake (orexigenic)
  • It stimulates growth hormone secretion by directly acting on the anterior pituitary
  • It increases gastric acid secretion and gastrointestinal motility to prepare the body for food intake
  • It regulates the distribution and rate of use of energy
  • It inhibits leptin release. It also causes lipolysis

Ghrelin levels increase during fasting, peaking just before food intake begins or when the subject is expecting a meal. The levels fall within 1 hour of the start of feeding.

Melanocyte-stimulating hormone, cholecystokinin, and leptin are anorexigenic and they decrease the appetite.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of fever with hemoptysis and hematuria. Investigations reveal the presence of antibodies against the glomerular basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hematuria and hemoptysis along with the presence of antibodies against the glomerular basement membrane narrow down the diagnosis to Goodpasture’s syndrome. 

Patients who develop antibodies against glomerular basement antigens frequently develop glomerulonephritis termed anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. When glomerulonephritis is combined with lung hemorrhage, as seen in our case, it is termed Goodpasture’s syndrome.

Certain features of the anti-GBM disease

  • The autoantibodies are directed against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and predominantly belong to the IgG group.
  • The clinical presentation can occur in two groups
    •  Younger men in their late twenties
      • They present in an explosive manner with hemoptysis, a sudden fall in hemoglobin, fever, dyspnoea, and hematuria
      • Lung hemorrhage is a usual presentation in smokers.
    • Older men and women in their sixties and seventies
      • These geriatric populations run a prolonged, asymptomatic course and end up with chronic renal failure with oliguria, and the prognosis is usually worse.

Characteristic histological pattern progresses as given below

  • Focal or segmental necrosis
  • Crescent formation (due to the destruction of capillaries by excessive cellular proliferation)
  • Interstitial nephritis with fibrosis and tubular atrophy

Immunofluorescent staining shows a linear pattern for IgG as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which source and cell produce testosterone?
questions.solution:
Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells from cholesterol.

Testosterone is also synthesized from androstenedione secreted by the adrenal cortex. Luteinizing hormone(LH) helps in the secretion of testosterone by increased formation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) via the G-protein- coupled LH receptor and Gs. 99% of the testosterone in plasma is bound to protein, 65% is bound to gonadal steroid–binding globulin (GBG) or sex steroid–binding globulin, and 33% to albumin.

Actions of testosterone:

  • Development of secondary sexual characters in males.
  • Increases protein synthesis and decreases protein destruction.
  • Maintain spermatogenesis along with FSH.
  • Libido

In some target cells testosterone is primarily converted into dihydrotestosterone(DHT) by 5α reductase. DHT helps in the development of male external genitalia, enlargement of the prostate and penis at the time of puberty, facial hair and acne development, and the temporal recession of the hairline.

questions.text:
Which of the following indicates the therapeutic index of a drug?

ED50 - Median effective dose

LD50 - Median lethal dose
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index (TI) refers to LD50/ED50. (Option D)

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio.

Mathematically, TI can be calculated in the following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 

Where,

  • LD50 (Median Lethal dose) is the minimum amount of drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population. 
  • ED50 (Median Effective dose) is the quantity of a drug that can produce desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with multiple sexual partners presents with a palmoplantar rash as seen below. On examination, he has epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of maculopapular rash with flu-like symptoms and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy points to secondary syphilis.

Secondary syphilis occurs within 6 weeks to 8 weeks of the onset of the primary chancre.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Onset of systemic manifestations includes symptoms such as malaise, headache, loss of appetite, sore throat
  • Generalized symmetric, asymptomatic maculopapular rash on the palms and soles.
  • Generalized adenopathy in 50% of cases
  • Condyloma lata is the classic finding. They are highly contagious exophytic broad excrescences that ulcer­ate. These are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area, and upper thighs.

The image below shows mucosal and cutaneous lesion of secondary syphilis.

Other options:

Option A: Psoriasis presents with itching and a papulosquamous rash commonly on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs. The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the Woronoff ring.

Option C: Meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis presents as acute fever with chills, malaise, and prostration. A petechial rash is seen early in the disease. Metastatic involvement of the joints, ears, eyes, lungs, and adrenals may occur. 

Option D: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, where SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

  • Primary Syphilis:

Chancre- Painless, indurated, usually single

Lymphadenopathy- Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

Dory flop sign- As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

 

Secondary Syphilis:

A & B: Generalized rash(non-itchy, no vesicles, and palm and sole involvement).

This is the most common lesion.

C & D: Condyloma lata.

E: Moth-eaten alopecia (Non-scarring)

F: Mucous patches(Flat erosions on the tongue which can coalesce and form snail track ulcers).These are the most infectious lesions.

G: Pigmentary plaques

H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Tertiary Syphilis:

Gummatous syphilis(deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor)

Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

CVS-Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

CNS-General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

 

Latent Syphilis-Period between secondary and tertiary syphilis, when the patient is asymptomatic clinically, and only serological evidence of infection is present.

  • Early latent- Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent- After 1 year of infection

questions.text: Which of the following is the  yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus?
questions.solution:
The right lateral rectus and left medial rectus represent a pair of yoke muscles.

Yoke muscles are also known as contralateral synergists. They are pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during version movements. Version movements also known as conjugate movements are synchronous (simultaneous) symmetric movements of both eyes in the same direction.

Examples:

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right LR and Left MR
  • Right SO and Left IR
  • Right IO and Left SR
  • Right SR and Left IO
  • Right IR and Left SO

(MR: Medial rectus; LR: Lateral rectus; SO: Superior oblique; IO: Inferior oblique; SR: Superior rectus; IR: Inferior rectus.)

These pairs of contralateral synergists receive equal and simultaneous innervation during version movements according to Herring’s Law of Equal Innervation.

Related Pearl: Extraocular muscles and their actions

Muscle Primary action Secondary action Tertiary action
Superior rectus Elevation Intorsion Adduction
Inferior rectus Depression Extorsion Adduction
Medial rectus Adduction --- --- 
Lateral rectus Abduction ---- ---
Superior oblique Intorsion Depression Abduction
Inferior oblique Extorsion Elevation Abduction

Related Pearl: Laws governing ocular movements

Sherrington’s Law of Reciprocal Innervation

During ocular motility, an increased flow of innervation to the contracting muscle is accompanied by the decreased flow of innervation to the relaxing antagonist muscle.

Example:

During dextroversion, an increased innervation flow to the right lateral rectus (LR) and left medial rectus (MR) is accompanied by decreased flow to the right MR and left LR.

Herring’s Law of Equal Innervation

According to this law, equal and simultaneous innervation flows from the brain to the contralateral synergists and contralateral antagonists.

Example:

  • During convergence: Both medial recti get equal innervation
  • During dextroversion: Right LR and left MR get equal innervation

questions.text: Giving class in a village for wound care after a dog bite by enacting it is which mode of health communication?
questions.solution:
The best method of giving a class in a village for wound care after a dog bite is by demonstration.

A demonstration is a group approach to health communication where the audience is educated on how to follow the advice by enacting it. Here the procedure is carried out step by step before an audience or the target group. It can bring about behavioural change in practices by arousing interest.

Other options:

Option A: A lecture is an oral presentation of facts, thoughts and ideas with help of chalk and board. Its effectiveness depends to a large extent on the speaker's ability and the comprehension of listeners. It would not be an effective tool in teaching a procedure like wound care.

Option B: Group discussion involves members interacting in a face-to-face situation. A group leader initiates the subject, encourages everyone to participate, takes discussion in the proper manner, and sums up the discussion in the end.

Option C: Flash card is a card that has words, numbers, or pictures on it that helps to learn. They are a form of visual aids in communication.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with a history of frothiness from the mouth and respiratory distress. An X-ray of the neonate is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of frothiness and respiratory distress and an X-ray showing a nasogastric (NG) tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas are suggestive of esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

Longitudinal furrow separates the trachea from the esophagus during development. Deviation or altered growth in this septum results in the formation of an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea called a tracheoesophageal fistula. It is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.

The newborn has excessive drooling and frothing soon after birth. On feeding, the baby develops choking and cyanosis. Regurgitation of secretion and feed through the fistulous tract into the lungs results in aspiration pneumonia.

Type C consists of proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF is the commonest. Here the air enters into stomach causing gastric distention which is seen as an air bubble. There is an inability to pass an NG tube for more than 7-10 cm, and a coiling in the proximal esophagus helps in the diagnosis.

Other options

Option A - Transient tachypnea of newborn is due to delayed clearance of lung fluid. They have tachypnea with minimal or no respiratory distress. Chest X-ray may show hyper-expanded lung fields, prominent vascular marking and prominent interlobar fissure.

Option B: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia occurs because of the failure to close the pleuroperitoneal membrane. Intestinal loops enter the thorax and compress the developing lung causing pulmonary hypoplasia. They present with respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen. Chest X-ray would show multiple air-filled spaces in the thorax, a shift of mediastinum, and the absence of an outline of the left diaphragm.

Option D: Respiratory distress syndrome/Hyaline membrane disease occurs primarily in premature infants due to a deficiency of surfactant in the alveoli. Clinical features include tachypnea, retractions, grunting, cyanosis, and decreased air entry. X-ray shows reticulogranular pattern, ground glass opacity, low lung volume, air bronchogram, and white-out lungs in severe disease.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheoesophageal Fistula

questions.text: Plasma sterilization is done by _____
questions.solution:
Plasma sterilization is done with hydrogen peroxide. The mechanism of action is a free radical injury with hydrogen peroxide. 

Arthroscopes, ureteroscope, etc. are sterilized by plasma sterilization. Sterilization control is Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus.

questions.text: A patient is referred to a higher center with the diagnosis of fracture. On examination, the forearm pulses were not palpable. An upper arm X-ray was done which is given below. Which artery is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the history and radiograph suggest a closed fracture of the shaft of the humerus. The brachial artery is the most commonly injured artery in this condition.

The radial nerve is commonly damaged in this condition.It manifests as an inability to dorsiflex the wrist and digits (wrist drop and finger drop). Numbness occurs on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 1/2 digits. 

Management of humerus shaft fractures: 

  • Conservative management is by reduction of the fracture and using a hanging cast or U-slab for 2-3 weeks followed by functional bracing
  • Surgical fixation by compression plating, interlocking intramedullary nail, semi-flexible pins, or an external fixator is indicated in:
    • Open fractures
    • Pathological fractures
    • Unstable humeral and forearm fractures (floating elbow)
    • Radial nerve palsy

The below X-ray shows shaft of humerus fracture.

 

The following image shows the course and branches of brachial artery in the arm:

questions.text: A study was conducted to compare MMR vaccine history in children with autism and children without autism. What kind of study is being done here?
questions.solution:
The above study design is typical of a case-control study. Children with autism are cases and without autism are control.

Case-control study is a type of obesrvational study used to test hypothesis. Here the study subjects are divided into cases- those having the disease of interest and controls- those without the disease of interest.  Odds ratio is a measure of strength of the association between risk factor and outcome in these studies.

Other options:

Option A: Cross-sectional study is based on a single examination of a cross-section of population at one point in time and the results can be projected on the whole population.

Option B: Cohort study divides subjects a into those with exposure and without exposure. This study gives relative risk which is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed. If this study were to divide children based on those who recieved MMR vaccine and those who did not recieve it to find out any association with autism, it would be called a cohort study.

Option D: A clinical trial is a type of experimental or interventional study. They are manily concerned with evaluating therapeutic agents, mainly drugs.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Odds ratio calculation (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • If the frequency of exposure is higher among cases, the OR will exceed 1, which indicates increased risk.
  • If the frequency is lower, then it will be <1, which can indicate possible protection.
  • If the OR is 1, then there is no association of risk with exposure or that the event is equally likely in both groups.

questions.text: A government plans to outline tobacco control laws. What is the level of prevention here?
questions.solution:
Creating tobacco control laws is a method of primary prevention.

Making tobacco control laws targets smokers who are already exposed to risk of smoking, who have not yet developed any disease. This aims to reduce smoking which is essentially a reduction of risk factor which is a primary prevention stratergy.

Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, whose aim is to prevent the disease from occuring. Its target population is healthy individuals. It commonly institutes activities that limit risk exposure or increase the immunity of individuals at risk to prevent a disease from progressing in a susceptible individual. They approaches can be as follows:

  • Population (mass) strategy where the target group is the whole population
  • A high-risk strategy where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to cause mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the condition least likely to cause mucormycosis is the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis. It is typically seen in patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised patients. Mucormycosis recently emerged as an important superinfection in COVID-19 patients, especially in India. The surge in cases is most likely due to diabetes mellitus and steroid use.

Risk factors for the infection include the following:

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Acidosis (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
  • Steroid treatment
  • Lymphomas and leukemias
  • Immunodeficiencies
  • Severe burns 

The rhino-orbital-cerebral is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients present with rhinitis, eye or facial pain, and facial numbness followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and swelling along with blurry vision. 

Patients can have local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembling the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis is made by biopsy with histopathologic examination. The biopsy shows characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

The below image shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis.

Treatment includes intravenous administration of amphotericin B and wide excision of necrotic tissues. Along with the reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors.

questions.text: Framework of external nose:

choices.text: Upper ½ is bony and lower ½ is cartilaginous
Upper 2/3rd is bony and lower 1/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.solution: External nose has upper 1/3rd bony part and lower 2/3rd cartilaginous part.

questions.text: The incisors of a child who had white patches on them which later turned brown are due to excessive supplementation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes dental fluorosis due to the over-supplementation of fluorine.

Dental fluorosis is characterized by mottling of tooth enamel due to ingestion of excessive fluoride. It occurs during calcification of teeth in childhood.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. It can present as:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L) Best seen on the upper incisors and permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, chalky-white patches developn on the teeth with loss of shiny lusture. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance.
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity affecting bone turnover. It causes osteoporosis due to stimulation of osteoclasts. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride. Prescribing fluoride supplements for children who drink fluoridated water and fluoride toothpaste in endemic areas should be avoided.

Interventions for fluorosis include

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • Chemical treatment in water treatment plants like Nalgonda technique using lime and alum.

The image below shows different stages of dental fluorosis:

questions.text: Infectivity is also known as?
questions.solution:
Infectivity is also known as the secondary attack rate.

Infectivity is the ability of an infectious agent to cause a new infection in a susceptible host. In diseases that are directly transmitted, it is measured by the secondary attack rate, which is the proportion of susceptible individuals that develop the infection after exposure to a primary case. It measures the communicability of the disease.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/ (Total number of susceptible close contacts).

Once a person gets infected, the time interval between invasion and appearance of the first sign or symptom is called as incubation period. During incubation, the agent multiplies in the host and builds up till it is sufficient to present as a disease.

As it is difficult to precisely calculate the incubation period, the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is used to calculate the incubation period. This is called serial interval.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

Incidence rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time ) x 1000

Incidence rate of spells of sickness = ( Number of spells of sickness starting in a specified period /Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time ) x 1000

Attack rate = ( Number of new cases of a disease in a specified period of time /Total population at risk during the given time ) x 100

Secondary attack rate = ( Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of the incubation period/Total number of exposed or susceptible contacts ) x 100

Prevalence = ( Number of all cases (new+old) of a specified disease at a given point in time/ Estimated population at the same point in time ) x 100

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about GFR?

GFR- Glomerular filtration rate

RPF- Renal Plasma Flow

choices.text: Increase in sympathetic function increases GFR

questions.solution:
The true statement about GFR is that the increase in RPF increases GFR.

With a constant glomerular hydrostatic pressure, an increase in blood flow into the glomerulus tends to increase the GFR and a lower rate of blood flow into the glomerulus tends to decrease the GFR.

GFR decreases with sympathetic stimulation as there is afferent arteriolar constriction. Strong activation of the renal sympathetic nerves can constrict the renal arterioles and decrease renal blood flow and GFR.

questions.text: What is the function of utricle and saccule?
questions.solution:
The function of utricle and saccule is linear acceleration.

Utricle and saccule which contain sensory epithelium called macula that are stimulated by linear acceleration and deceleration or gravitational pull during the head tilts.

The ampullated end of each semicircular canal contains a thickened ridge of neuroepithelium called crista ampullaris that respond to angular acceleration and deceleration.

Hearing is mediated by the organ of Corti on the basilar membrane of the inner ear.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is most appropriate to be used for the treatment of diarrhea in a patient who was treated for colorectal carcinoma with 5-fluorouracil?
questions.solution:
Loperamide is used for the treatment of diarrhea in a patient who was treated for colorectal carcinoma with 5-flurouracil.

Loperamide is a drug with μ opioid receptor activity and is an orally active antidiarrheal agent. The drug is more potent than morphine as an antidiarrheal agent and penetrates the CNS poorly.

It is effective in patients with 5-fluorouracil-induced diarrhea and can be regarded as the treatment of choice. Loperamide is effective against traveler’s diarrhea and can be used alone or in combination. If clinical improvement in acute diarrhea does not occur within 48 hours, loperamide should be discontinued.

Overdosage can lead to constipation, CNS depression (especially in children), and paralytic ileus.

Other options:

Option A: Ciprofloxacin is used in the treatment of diarrhea due to gastrointestinal infection. It is given in traveler’s diarrhea and reduces the duration of loose stools by 1–3 days. Ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin can cure most patients with enteric fever caused by Salmonella typhi, as well as bacteremic nontyphoidal infections in patients with HIV. 

Option C: Atropine and atropine-like drugs are used in diarrhea associated with irritation of the lower bowel, such as mild dysenteries and diverticulitis.

Option D: Ornidazole has a role as an antiprotozoal drug and is used in the treatment of susceptible protozoal infections and for the treatment of anaerobic bacterial infections.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5HT-4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: An 3-year old child is having amblyopia in right eye. What is the preferred treatment for this child?
questions.solution:
The treatment of amblyopia in this child is by occlusion of the normal eye, in this case, the left eye. 

Amblyopia or 'lazy eye' is a developmental defect of spatial visual processing that occurs in the central visual pathways of the eye. It is reversible if treated appropriately at the right time during the development phase(0-8 years of age) but is most commonly seen in the first 3 years of life. It is a condition with unilateral or bilateral subnormal vision without any local abnormality in the eye.

It is most commonly associated with comitant squint and can be due to retinal defects, strabismus, high anisometropia with aniseikonia(a difference in the retinal image size between the two eyes).

Amblyopic eyes have a characteristic vision which has:

  • The crowding phenomenon where single letter vision is better than when presented in a row.
  • A drop in visual acuity when viewed through grey neutral density filters
  • Decreased recognition, contrast sensitivity, spatial localization, saccadic amplitudes, and pursuit eye movements.

Treatment includes occluding the normal eye for 6-12 weeks.

If there is a vision problem with an underlying cause then that should be corrected initially. The brain uses the stronger eye to perceive images and hence the brain has to be trained and forced to use the amblyopic or lazy eye by occluding the normal eye.

By occluding the normal eye, the amblyopic eye gets stimulated and gets corrected. Occlusion should be total and should be changed when it is dirty or loose.

In children less than 8 years the occlusion has to be done in a way so that constant occlusion of the normal eye does not make it amblyopic too.

It is done corresponding to the child's age (x) at a ratio of x:1. e.g if the child is 5 years old then the normal eye is occluded for 5 days and removed while only the amblyopic eye is occluded on the 6th day. It is continued in a similar fashion for 6-12 weeks. 

In infants, part-time occlusion (a few hours a day) is done while in children above 8 years, constant occlusion is advised.

However, the underlying cause of amblyopia should also be corrected for complete resolution.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is found to be deficient in Von Gierke's disease?
questions.solution:
The enzyme deficient in Von Gierke's disease is glucose-6- phosphatase.

Von Gierke's disease is an autosomal recessive glycogen storage disorder, caused due to deficiency of the glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme.

Clinical presentation is often in infancy (usually at 3-4 months), and usually presents with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemic seizures, or both. Affected children have fat cheeks (doll-like faces), relatively thin extremities, short stature, and protuberant abdomen due to massive hepatomegaly, and enlarged kidneys. Easy bruising and epistaxis are common due to increased bleeding time. Other findings include delayed puberty, polycystic ovaries, osteopenia, pancreatitis, neutropenia, hepatic adenoma, and renal diseases.

Clinical presentation and laboratory findings of hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, ketosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia point to a suspected diagnosis of von Gierke's disease. A definitive diagnosis can be made by liver biopsy or gene-based variant analysis by single-gene sequencing or gene panels. Histopathology of the liver shows the intracytoplasmic accumulation of glycogen.

Treatment focuses on maintaining euglycemia. Nasogastric infusion of glucose or uncooked cornstarch is administered in infancy. For older children, uncooked cornstarch may be given orally. Dietary avoidance of fructose and galactose is necessary for these patients. Orthotropic liver transplantation is a potential cure for von Gierke's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows the highest concentration in serum?
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulin G(IgG) shows the highest concentration in serum.

It constitutes about 80 percent of the total immunoglobulin in the serum. It is distributed approximately equally between the intravascular and extravascular compartments

IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta and provides natural passive immunity to the newborn.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: The following condition seen in the image results from failure of fusion of :

choices.text: Lateral nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Lateral nasal prominence and mandibular prominence
Medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Medial nasal prominence and mandibular prominence

questions.solution:
Cleft lip is due to failure of fusion between the medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence.

Various defects of fusion of prominences in the face region are as follows:

  • Cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It can vary in severity from a small notch in the upper lip to a double cleft extending into both the nostrils. There is also associated underdevelopment of the part of the maxilla that bears the incisors.
  • Median (midline) cleft lip is a rare defect occurring due to failure of fusion of the two medial nasal prominences in the midline.
  • Oblique facial cleft is caused by the failure of the maxillary prominence to fuse with the lateral nasal prominence along the line of the nasolacrimal groove. The nasolacrimal duct is exposed to the surface in these cases.

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 5–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: A young person with recurrent seasonal conjunctivitis presents with itchiness and watering in the eyes. What is the most likely cell involved in the immediate phase of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of allergic reactions suggest Type 1 hypersensitivity which is mediated by immunoglobulin E (IgE) binding to mast cells.

Immediate (Type I) Hypersensitivity, also called allergic reactions or allergies is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to an IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It has two phases.

Early phase: The mediators produced by the mast cells are responsible for most of the immediate hypersensitivity reactions. Histamine and leukotrienes are released rapidly from the sensitized mast cells and trigger intense immediate reactions characterized by edema, mucus secretion, and smooth muscle spasm.

Other mediators involved in the early phase are, 

  • Enzymes: neutral proteases (chymase, tryptase) and acid hydrolases
  • Proteoglycans: heparin and chondroitin sulfate
  • Lipid mediators: Platelet-activating factor (PAF)

Late-phase: The late-phase reaction is characterized by the recruitment of leukocytes, that amplify and sustain the inflammatory response without exposure to the triggering antigen.

Mediators involved in the late phase of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction are:

  • Cytokines: TNF, IL-1, IL-4, IL-5, and chemokines (eotaxin)
  • Leukocytes (eosinophils)
  • Major Basic Protein (MBP)
  • Eosinophil cationic protein

The sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity

Though eosinophils and neutrophils are involved later in the pathogenesis, mast cells are central to the development of immediate hypersensitivity.

Related Pearl: Disorders Caused by Immediate Hypersensitivity

Clinical Syndrome

Clinical and Pathologic Manifestations

Anaphylaxis (may be caused by drugs, bee sting, food)

Fall in blood pressure (shock) caused by vascular dilation; airway obstruction due to laryngeal edema

Bronchial asthma

Airway obstruction caused by bronchial smooth muscle hyperactivity; inflammation and tissue injury caused by late-phase reaction

Allergic rhinitis, sinusitis (hay fever)

Increased mucus secretion; inflammation of upper airways, sinuses

Food allergies

Increased peristalsis due to contraction of intestinal muscles

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the left posterior choanae. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma and the most appropriate step in its management is surgical excision.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma(JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. 

Patients usually present with, profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis (most common presentation). A mass may be present in either the postnatal space, resulting in progressive nasal obstruction, or nasopharynx, where it may obstruct both choanae. The mass is firm in consistency, but digital palpation of the same should not be done. If the mass obstructs the eustachian tube, conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion may be observed. Proptosis, swelling of the cheeks, broadening of the nasal bridge, and involvement of 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerves may occur.

JNA can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and carotid angiography. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space is a characteristic CT finding of JNA. This is known as the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign, as shown in the image below.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice though radiotherapy and chemotherapy monotherapy or in combination have also been used. Radiotherapy(Option C) is considered for recurrent inaccessible tumours. Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, vincristine, and dacarbazine is used in the case of very aggressive recurrent tumours and residual tumours. Hormonal therapy can be used as a primary or adjunctive treatment.

questions.text: Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein is a major component of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein forms a major component of the organic matrix of renal casts.

Tamm-Horsfall protein, also known as uromodulin, is the most common protein present in urine and is produced in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. They are membrane-bound, glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchored proteins that are released by proteolytic cleavage at the apical membrane. It is secreted as the most abundant protein in normal human urine (20 to 100 mg/day) and is not expressed by macula densa cells or the downstream distal convoluted tubule (DCT)

They form the major organic matrix of all renal casts and play a role in the modulation of innate immunity in the kidney and inflammation during kidney injury. Uromodulin is coded by the UMOD gene, and mutation of this can lead to medullary cystic kidney disease (MCKD II) and familial juvenile hyperuricemic nephropathy.

Casts are cylindrical structures that are formed in the DCT and collecting ducts. They assume the shape and size of the lumen in which they are formed. Several factors favor cast formation, such as urine stasis, low pH, and high concentration. All casts have an organic matrix composed primarily of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein. Casts are the only elements in urine sediments that are specific to renal origin.

Other options:

Option A: Thrombi occurring in heart chambers or the aortic lumen are designated mural thrombi. Thrombi often have grossly and microscopically apparent laminations called lines of Zahn, which are pale platelet and fibrin deposits alternating with darker red cell–rich layers.

Option B: Curschmann spirals are a characteristic finding in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimens of patients with atopic asthma formed due to the extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles.

Option D: In multiple myeloma, the malignant plasma cells often secrete free, unpaired κ or λ light chains which are referred to as Bence-Jones proteins.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: Fundoscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). 

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Risk factors include:

  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Mucormycosis
  • Varicella infection
  • Radiation exposure
  • Trauma

Etiology:

  • Emboli - emboli having carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are - cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli
  • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
  • Retinal arteritis with obliteration
  • Angiospasm
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Thrombophilic disorders

Clinical features are:

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Amaurosis fugax - transient monocular blindness that is due to ischemia. As seen in this patient.
  • Direct pupillary reflex is absent
  • Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive

Fundus examination shows:

  • Marked attenuation of arteries – thread like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein – cattle track appearance
  • Cherry red spot
  • Severe edema 
  • Retinal pallor

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photo disruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Other options:

Option B: In CRVO, funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots.

Option C: Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy can have microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhage, and mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA). Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is characterized by neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE).

Option D: In cystoid macular edema, the fundus shows a dull foveal reflex/absent foveal reflex. The fluorescein angiography image shows a flower petal pattern.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: The SAFE strategy given by WHO forms the mainstay of the management of trachoma. What does the S in this acronym represent?
questions.solution:
The S in the acronym stands for surgery.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFEstrategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the TRIC (trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis) serovars A, B, Ba, C. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage. The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles contain Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • Corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

The cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. The patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed Herbert follicles)
  • Corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

The below image shows Herbert's pits. 

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with `FISTO’ is in use.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: Hand washing during COVID-19 is what level of prevention?
questions.solution:
Hand washing during COVID-19 is a method of Primary prevention.

COVID-19 is an infectious respiratory illness caused by the coronavirus. Infection control measures like immunization, hand washing, personal hygiene and public health measures such as sanitation serve as a holistic primary prevention strategy.

Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of a disease, whose aim is to prevent the disease from occurring. Its target population is healthy individuals. It commonly institutes activities that limit risk exposure or increase the immunity of individuals at risk to prevent a disease from progressing in a susceptible individual. The approaches can be as follows:

  • Population (mass) strategy where the target group is the whole population
  • A high-risk strategy is where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones does not directly act on the the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Gastrin does not directly act upon the pancreas. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth.

CCK:

Stimulates:

  • Pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • Pancreatic bicarbonate secretion
  • Gallbladder contraction
  • Growth of exocrine pancreas

Inhibits:

  • Gastric emptying

Secretin increases HCO3- secretion by ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum.

It is secreted by the S cells in the upper small intestine.

Functions of secretion are:

  • Primary function
    • ↑ HCO3- secretion by ductal cells of pancreas and duodenum
  • Other functions
    • Augments the effects of CCK
    • Inhibits gastrin release
    • ↓ gastric acid secretion
    • Contraction of pyloric sphincter
    • Exerts trophic effect on the pancreas

Insulin secretion is normally stimulated by Glucagon like peptide-1(GLP 1).

Glucagon-like peptide–1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP) are called incretins and are potent stimulators of insulin secretion. They also inhibit glucagon secretion. They are released in the gastrointestinal tract after a person eats a meal. They then cause an “anticipatory” increase in blood insulin in preparation for the glucose and amino acids to be absorbed from the meal.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient who was using presbyopic glasses for the past few years is now able to comfortably read the newspaper without the glasses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of improvement in near vision of a presbyopic patient is termed the second sight phenomenon. This is seen due to index myopia caused by the formation of nuclear cataracts.

Presbyopia, also known as the eyesight of old age, is a condition of physiological insufficiency of accommodation leading to a progressive fall in near vision. The treatment of presbyopia is the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

In nuclear cataracts, nuclear sclerosis occurs leading to an increase in refractive index. This leads to progressive myopia known as index myopia. When a presbyopic patient develops a nuclear cataract, this increase in the refractive index of the lens compensates for the physiological insufficiency of accommodation that the patient has.

Thus, a patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles due to this improvement in near vision, termed second sight. At the same time, this increased refractive index causes a deterioration in far vision.

Option B: Index hypermetropia occurs in cortical cataracts and sclerosis that lead to a decrease in the refractive index of the lens in old age. In such patients, there will be worsening of the near vision which does not align with the history of a presbyopic being able to read with his glasses.

Option C: Presbyopia occurs due to a decrease in the accommodative power of the crystalline lens with increasing age, and thus does not regress spontaneously. It can however be easily corrected with the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male presented with yellowish discoloration of his skin and sclera. He is otherwise normal. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. He also gives a history of similar episodes in the past following any illness. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL
Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL
Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette points toward the diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

This patient's mild jaundice seen only during a period of stress along with an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST, and ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production. UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Precipitating factors in Gilbert syndrome:

  • Dehydration
  • Fasting
  • Menstrual periods
  • Illness
  • Vigorous exercise.

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment.

Option B: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in babies. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Unconjugated bilirubin is elevated. Isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a 20-year-old male is less likely to be due to Criggler Najar type 1 syndrome. It is because patients usually die in infancy or early childhood despite the best treatment.

Option D: Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Increased conjugated bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy does not show black colored liver

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of dicumarol?

choices.text: Inhibits vitamin K dependant clotting factors

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of Dicumarol is by inhibiting the synthesis of Vit K-dependent clotting factors in the liver.

Dicumarol and warfarin competitively inhibit the gamma-carboxylation system due to structural similarity with vitamin K. Therefore, they can act as anticoagulants used for therapeutic purposes.

Vitamin K epoxide is reduced to the quinone form by epoxide reductase, which is sensitive to inhibition by warfarin and dicoumarol.

Other options:

Option A: Heparin is a powerful-acting anticoagulant that acts indirectly by activating plasma antithrombin III. The heparin-AT III complex then binds to clotting factors of the intrinsic and common pathways (Xa, IIa, IXa, XIa, Xlla, and XIIIa) and inactivates them.

Option C: Drugs like tranexamic acid inhibit plasminogen activation and dissolution of the clot, and are used to check fibrinolysis-associated bleeding.

Option D: Rivaroxaban and apixaban are active direct inhibitors of activated factor Xa which has become available for prophylaxis and treatment of DVT.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

 

 

Classification of Anticoagulants

2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)    Oral DTI

Parenteral DTI
