  Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin
 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors  Unfractionated heparin
Low molecular weight heparins  

Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin
Fondaparinux
 
4) Direct Oral Factor Xa Inhibitors  Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

questions.text: A 70-year-old male comes with complaints of hip pain. An X-ray of the hip shows lytic lesions and serum calcium levels are elevated. Bone marrow plasma cells are 42% and the cells seen are given in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In an elderly male patient, the presence of hypercalcemia, lytic bone lesions, bone marrow plasma cells of more than 10%, and the characteristic Mott cell as seen in the image suggest multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia. The incidence of multiple myeloma increases with age, and it is more commonly seen in males than in females.

Signs and symptoms

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia elevated ESR, Hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
  • Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20% plasma cells (normal is < 5%) and presence of Dutcher bodies, Russel bodies, and Mott cells.
  • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation)

 

Option A: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen. Peripheral smear contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.

Option B: Acute lymphocytic leukemia presents with a hypercellular marrow that is packed with lymphoblasts. These lymphoblasts, when compared to myeloblasts, have more condensed chromatin with less prominent nucleoli.

Option C: In chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), patients typically present with a dragging sensation in the abdomen due to splenomegaly or splenic infarct, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. The peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described as having a garden party or a college girl appearance. 

Related Pearl: Some Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

 

Description

Russell bodies

They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig).

Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

Dutcher bodies

PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions containing Ig seen in some of the plasma cells are called Dutcher bodies.

Flame cells

Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm are called flame cells.

PAS: Periodic acid Schiff

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the effect of the mutation causing sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Sickle cell anemia is characterized by the replacement of glutamate by valine at the 6th position.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to the T-to-A point mutation in the sixth codon of the β-globin gene. This results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This leads to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Painful bone crisis- hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    • Adolescence or early adulthood- auto splenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features include priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

 The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled RBCs on peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike.

Disease-modifying drugs such as hydroxyurea can be given to patients with sickle cell anemia since it reduces the incidence of adverse vaso-occlusive vents. Blood transfusions are used to treat and prevent complications of sickle cell disease, including preparation for surgery, symptomatic anemia, acute stroke, multi-organ failure, and acute chest syndrome

questions.text: Identify the histological image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium.

The deepest layer has columnar cells, the middle layers are made up of polyhedral cells and the surface layer has cells that are large and shaped like an umbrella.

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and part of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called urothelium. In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: On palpation at the site marked by the red arrow on the image a bony ridge is felt. What is the vertebral level of the marked arrow?
questions.solution:
A body ridge felt when palpated a few centimeters from the suprasternal notch represents the angle of Louis/sternal angle. Recent data place the sternal angle between the T4 vertebra and the upper half of the T5 vertebra in the majority of adults.

The mediastinum is divided into superior and inferior by a line joining the sternal angle to the T4-T5 intervertebral disc. 

The sternal plane is traditionally reported to pass through the intervertebral disc between the T4-T5 vertebrae posteriorly and the manubriosternal joint (sternal angle or angle of Louis) at the level of the second costal cartilage anteriorly. It can be used as an anatomical landmark for structures of the mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Angle of Louis

The angle of Loius (sternal angle) is formed by the manubriosternal joint at the level of 2nd costal cartilage anteriorly.

A plane joining the angle of Louis to the intervertebral disc between T4 and T5, called the sternal plane marks the following anatomical landmarks: 

  • Separates superior mediastinum form inferior mediastinum. 
  • Marks the position superior limit of pericardium.
  • Bifurcation of pulmonary trunk
  • Bifurcation of trachea (newer studies shows its lower)  
  • Origin of arch of aorta.
  • Site where superior venacava pierces the pericardium.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a fever, cough, red eyes, running nose, and rash. The appearance of the child is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a given clinical vignette and the rash has measles. 

Measles is a common cause of fever with rash that spread via droplets. It is characterised by a prodrome of cough, conjunctivitis and coryza along with fever. Koplik spots are white grain lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite to the lower second molar. A reddish macular rash begins behind the ears on the 4th day, rapidly becomes maculopapular and spreads to the face, neck, chest, arms, trunk, thighs and legs.

Other options:

Option A: Mumps is caused by a paramyxovirus and spread by droplets and contact. It causes fever, malaise unilateral or bilateral parotitis. It also causes epididymo-orchitis in males.

Option C: Chickenpox is caused by varicella zoster and spreads by contact and airborne. It has a prodrome of fever, malaise, anorexia and headache which is followed by a rash in 1-2 days. It has pruritic erythematous macules that first appear on the trunk and spreads to face and extremities that evolve into papules, vesicles and pustules that become crusted. The presence of several crops of lesions that are in different stages of evolution is a characteristic of varicella.

Option D: Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) is caused by parvovirus B19 transmitted by airborne route. The prodromal consists of low-grade fever, headache and mild upper respiratory tract infection. An erythematous slapped cheeked rash that first appears on the face is characteristic. A macular rash then spreads to the trunk and extremities that undergoes central clearing giving a lacy or reticulated pattern.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resemble the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

The rhino-orbital-cerebral is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients present with rhinitis, eye or facial pain, and facial numbness, followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and swelling along with blurry vision.

Diagnosis is made by biopsy with histopathologic examination. The biopsy shows characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

The image below shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis:

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment of the infection includes 4 steps:

  1. Initiation of therapy (amphotericin B) as early as possible. Posaconazole can also be used in the management of this condition.
  2. Surgical debridement
  3. Reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors
  4. Treatment of underlying malignancy if present.

The image below shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis:

 

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of a black or greyish membranes in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 35- year old woman presented to the clinic with the symptoms of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Further examination reveals conductive hearing loss with Rinne test negative. A reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a glomus tumor.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign middle ear neoplasm. It is seen frequently in middle-aged females. The tumor consists of paraganglionic cells from the neural crest. Glomus tumor is an extremely vascular benign tumor.

There are two types of glomus tumors: glomus jugulare and glomus tympanicum. Glomus jugulare arises from the dome of the jugular bulb and invades the hypotympanum. Glomus tympanicum arises from the promontory of the middle ear.

Clinical features include conductive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus- earliest symptoms. Otoscopy examination shows a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane as a "rising sun" appearance since the tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear. Paralysis of the 9th to 12th cranial nerves can also occur. An audible bruit over the mastoid is heard on auscultation in all the stages of the tumor.

Other options:

Option A: Acute otitis media presents with throbbing earache and a red and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks on examination. Tuning fork tests reveal a conductive type of hearing loss.

Option B: Chronic otitis media presents with mucoid or mucopurulent ear discharge, the conductive type of hearing loss, and central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Middle ear mucosa can be seen through the perforation.  

Option D: Serous otitis media presents with hearing loss, delayed and defective speech, and mild earaches associated with upper respiratory tract infections. Otoscopy reveals a dull, opaque, and retracted tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex, a thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus, fluid levels, and air bubbles behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated if the infant has galactosemia. 

Classical galactosemia is due to a complete deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase leading to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate. Infants present with jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, hypoglycemia, seizures, irritability, and feeding difficulties. Breast milk contains galactose and hence these infants should not be fed breast milk.

The contraindications to breastfeeding can be grouped as follows:

  • Absolute contraindications to breastfeeding:
  1. Classical galactosemia
  2. HTLV (Human T-cell lymphocyte virus) or ebola infection
  3. The mother is an active illicit drug user.
  • Relative contraindications for breastfeeding:
  1. Maternal HIV- risk of not breastfeeding overweigh risk of HIV transmission
  2. Hepatitis B- can be fed after infants receive hepatitis B immunoglobulin and vaccine
  3. Active herpes lesion- feed with the other breast
  4. Tuberculosis in mother- hold until completion of 2 weeks of therapy and then start
  5. Varicella infection- Infant should receive immune globulin and have no contact with active lesions
  • Not a contraindication:
  1. Alcohol consumption
  2. Smoking tobacco
  3. Hepatitis C infection

questions.text: The culture media that is used to differentiate lactose fermenters and non-lactose fermenters is______
questions.solution:
MacConkey agar is used to distinguish lactose fermenters (pink) from non-lactose fermenters (colourless or pale). It is a selective and differential media.

It is selective because bile salts and dyes inhibit gram-positive organisms and gram-negative cocci. It is differential because the pH indicator turns pink-red when the lactose is fermented.

Contents of MacConkey agar: Mnemonic: PLANT

  • Peptone 
  • Lactose                 
  • Agar
  • Neutral red
  • Sodium Taurocholate

Lactose-fermenting organisms (Eg: E. coli) produce a pink colour, and non-lactose-fermenting organisms (Shigella sp., Salmonella sp.) do not change the colour as shown below. 

Other options:

Option B: Alkaline bile salt agar (BSA) at pH 8.2 is a simple medium used for the culture of Vibrio cholerae. The colonies are similar to those on nutrient agar.

Option C: Thayer–Martin agar is used for Nesseria.

Option D: Sabouraud Dextrose agar is used for fungal culture.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice for shock in a child with severe acute malnutrition?
questions.solution:
The fluid of choice for shock in a child with severe acute malnutrition(SAM) is Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose.

If a child with SAM is lethargic or unconscious with cold extremities plus decreased capillary refill (>3 sec) or weak fast pulse, it is said to be in shock. Intravenous fluid resuscitation in SAM is only recommended in those with shock. IV fluids that can be used in these children are

  • Ringer lactate with 5% dextrose
  • Half-normal saline with 5% dextrose 
  • Half-strength Darrow solution with 5% dextrose.

If any of the above mixtures is not available, only then ringer lactate can be used.

10% glucose is given orally or IV in SAM to treat hypoglycemia and is not used to replenish intravascular volume.

questions.text: How much oxygen is given to a term infant with respiratory distress during resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Resuscitation in term infants is done by using 21% oxygen or room air.

In term infants with apnea, gasping or heart rate <100/min, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is given by bag-mask device in room air with 21% oxygen. Room air in term infants is effective and may reduce the risk of hyperoxia, reduced cerebral blood flow and generation of free radicals.

If there is no improvement in 30 seconds, ventilative corrective steps should be taken and then oxygen concentration titrated as needed to obtain the expected saturation. If the heart rate falls below 60 then chest compressions are started, intubated and FIO2 is increased to 100%.

Resuscitation of most preterm infants can be initiated with a slightly higher fraction of inspired oxygen (21–30%) and titrated as needed.

questions.text: The image shown here is used for the diagnosis of _______
questions.solution:
The image given below shows the Tzanck smear which is a rapid, diagnostic method. It is used for the diagnosis of the Herpes simplex virus (HSV).

Tzanck cells are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin.

Tzanck smear is a cytological examination of skin blisters. After rupturing the roof of the blister, the floor is scraped with a blade and the material is transferred onto a microscopic slide and fixed. Slides are stained with Giemsa, Wright’s stain, or toluidine blue and examined under the microscope. Tzanck smear is also used in the diagnosis of Hailey-Hailey disease, Darier’s disease, hand-foot-and-mouth disease, etc.

Other options:

Option A: HIV can be detected by virus isolation, detection of antibodies to various antigens of the virus, and by detection of viral DNA, RNA, or antigens.

Option B: Hepatitis B virus is usually detected by viral markers in the serum.

Option C: Koilocytes are characteristically seen in HPV infections, such as Condyloma acuminatum. Koilocytes are lining cells that have perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolization.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor participates in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation?
questions.solution:
Factor VII participates in the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

The prothrombin time (PT) assay is done to assesses the function of the proteins in the extrinsic pathway- Factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen.

Factor VIII, IX, and XI participate in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.

Factor VIII is a protein involved in the intrinsic pathway and its function is assessed by the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about health propaganda?

choices.text: It aids in developing a reflective behaviour

questions.solution:
The correct statement about propaganda is that it appeals to emotions.

The difference between health education and health propaganda is given below:

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused and stimulated
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour; Aims at impulsive action 
Reasoning/emotion Appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour The process is behaviour centred The process is information centred

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngeal cancer stage T1b N0 M0?

choices.text: Both vocal cords involved and fixed
Both vocal cords involved and mobile
One vocal cord involved and fixed
One vocal cord involved and mobile

questions.solution:
In stage T1b N0 M0 laryngeal cancer, both the vocal cords are involved and are mobile. 

TNM classification of glottic carcinoma :

Stage Description

T2a Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with normal vocal cord mobility
T2b Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or  minor thyroid cartilage erosion
T4a Tumour invades thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissue beyond the larynx
T4b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures
